headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thanks for joining our call. Although challenging, 2009 was a year of positive change for First Horizon. Looking beyond our bottom line fourth quarter and full year loss, we made progress in executing our strategic plan
componenttext: Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thanks for joining our call. Although challenging, 2009 was a year of positive change for First Horizon. Looking beyond our bottom line fourth quarter and full year loss, we made progress in executing our strategic plan to reposition First Horizon for consistent, significant and long-term profitability.  A healthy balance sheet is critical to long-term success, and we believe that 2009's actions materially bolstered our balance sheet.  We have substantially improved liquidity. Our core deposits grew significantly last year, enabling us to reduce reliance on wholesale funding and retire debt. Additionally, our capital and reserve position is currently one of the strongest in the industry. We continue to identify and aggressively deal with credit issues. We increased our allowance to loans for the year, recognized problem loans and wrote them down to net realizable value. As a result of the work performed on our loan portfolios, non-performers and net charge-offs began to decline in the second half of 2009. In fact, non-performing assets have now been steady to declining for three consecutive quarters, indicative of the hard work and success of strengthened credit policies implemented and overseen by Greg and his very experienced team.We reduced risk by strengthening our balance sheet through the ongoing wind-down of our National Specialty Lending and Mortgage businesses. Since December 2007, we have reduced our National wind-down loans by 40%, including an 85% reduction in our National residential construction portfolios.  As part of derisking our balance sheet and as a continuation of efforts to exit non-core businesses, we sold $14 billion of mortgage servicing in 2009. Our servicing portfolio is down from a peak $108 billion to $40 billion at the end of 2009.Competitive business model is also critical to long-term success, and in 2009, we focused on strengthening our core businesses, Regional Banking and Capital Markets. Emphasis on customer service helped grow our Regional Bank's average core deposits 12% in 2009. Relationship banking and greater pricing discipline enabled the Regional Bank's net interest margin to expand 15 basis points in 2009. We remain committed to serving our core customers and made nearly $2 billion of new and renewed loans in 2009. Soft demand, weak line usage, credit-related actions and normal portfolio run off led to a decline in loans outstanding over the course of the year, however. During 2009, we also implemented a new line of business structure in our Regional Bank to incorporate improved performance discipline, support consistent execution across geographies and increase scalability.  FTN Financial is an attractive business for us, with high returns on capital. In 2009, our Capital Markets business had an outstanding year. Fixed income revenues were a record $600 million, up 22% from 2008. Fixed income revenues began to normalize in the second half of 2009 but remained very strong relative to historical levels. During 2009, we also identified cost-cutting and efficiency measures that we've already begun to implement. BJ will provide more insight in a few minutes.Turning to the fourth quarter on Slide 4, we took several actions that negatively affected the bottom line but should be beneficial over the long term. We exited a couple of non-core business locations and terminated contracts that had diminished in value as we exited our National businesses. These actions resulted in a fourth quarter pre-tax impact of $31 million or 35% of our pre-tax loss. Additionally, as part of our focused monitoring of credit issues, we increased our mortgage repurchase reserve, resulting in $59 million of expense, significantly driving up our environmental cost for the fourth quarter.Credit quality trends, which Greg will detail for you, were encouraging. Linked-quarter provision expense declined $50 million and charge-offs declined $19 million, and the allowance for credit losses was a strong 4.95% despite a $48 million reserve decrease. Our capital ratios ended the year on strong footing, with Tangible Common Equity to Tangible Assets at 7.8% and Tier 1 Common at 9.8%. Consolidated net interest margin expanded 23 basis points from last year's fourth quarter levels, as we concentrated on better pricing and growing customer deposits while the impact of non-accruals lessened. All in all, 2009 was a year during which we took major steps towards accomplishing our goals of returning First Horizon to sustained profitability and driving solid shareholder returns. I'll be back later for some closing comments. BJ will now take you through the fourth quarter financial results. BJ?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. Let me quickly go over the quarter's consolidated financials on Slide 6.  As Bryan mentioned, our fourth quarter EPS was a loss of $0.32 after discontinued operations. And we had a net loss of $71 million, including
componenttext: Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. Let me quickly go over the quarter's consolidated financials on Slide 6.  As Bryan mentioned, our fourth quarter EPS was a loss of $0.32 after discontinued operations. And we had a net loss of $71 million, including $31 million in restructuring-related costs. As you can see, there were a lot of moving parts this quarter, and so I'll try to go over them in a little more detail over the next few minutes. If you turn to Slide 7, our pre-tax, pre-provision highlights by business, you can see our core businesses, Regional Banking and Capital Markets, posted solid results, while high expenses in our wind-down businesses, as well as in our Corporate segment negatively impacted pre-tax, pre-provision. You can see fourth quarter showed some positive trends in the Bank and Capital Markets business, with solid pre-tax, pre--provision earnings, good margin expansion in the Bank, good fee income and reduced non-interest expenses. If you look specifically at the Regional Bank, our pre-tax, pre-provision earnings were up 42% from the third quarter, as expenses were lower, including reduced foreclosure costs in the Bank. NII remains steady in the Bank, as well as the impact from lower loan balances was offset by improved net interest margin. And in fact, in the Bank, the margin expanded 17 basis points to 4.97%. And average core deposits were up 4% in the Bank. In Capital Markets, our pre-tax, pre-provision earnings remain solid and steady. Fixed income revenues were slightly down from last quarter, as the average daily revenues declined to $1.8 million a day from $1.9 million. And commensurate with that, expenses declined 5% due to lower variable comp. Going forward, we expect continued positive trends in Regional Banking and further normalization over time in Capital Markets' revenues. Mortgage and National Specialty Lending were a significant drag on our consolidated earnings for the quarter, with higher environmental costs for the mortgage repurchase reserve, which I'll give a little more detail on in a few minutes.  During the quarter, we took several actions to better position our company for the long term, contributing to a $32 million pre-tax loss that shows up in the Corporate segment, and I'll detail these items on Slide 8. So if we turn to Slide 8, consistent with what we've talked about previously in our overall focus on driving efficiencies, as well as a review we undertook in 2009 of all of our businesses to better position us for sustained profitability going forward, we took several restructuring actions in the fourth quarter. And you can see the pre-tax, cash and non-cash impact shown on Slide 8. First one, we canceled a significant vendor contract that resulted in a $13 million  charge. We divested our First Horizon Insurance business in Atlanta, and we sold a non-strategic remittance processing business. Collectively, these actions negatively impacted pre-tax income by $17 million. And included various other smaller charges, these items totaled $31 million pre-tax impact. And although these actions negatively impacted fourth quarter pre-tax earnings, they should improve our efficiency and performance over the long term, beginning in 2010.If you flip to Slide 9, total expenses rose nearly 12% from last quarter due to higher environmental costs and restructuring and efficiency charges. These offset lower expenses in the Regional Bank that were down 9% and lower Capitals Markets expenses, which were down 5%.  In terms of our efficiency actions that we've talked to you about previously, we've now identified over $100 million in efficiency expense savings, up from an earlier $50 million to $75 million target. These cost saves will be achieved by streamlining operations and improving processes. In 2009, we've implemented about 2/3 of these actions and expect the remainder to be fully implemented in 2010.We're still facing significant environmental costs, which totaled about $73 million in the fourth quarter compared to third quarter's $47 million. We incurred $13 million of foreclosure costs and $59 million of expense related to our mortgage repurchase provision. The addition to our mortgage repurchase reserve is based on an increase in repurchase submissions we've seen coming into the pipeline and slower resolutions in the existing, resulting in higher estimated inherent losses. We had $17 million of actual realized charge-offs in the fourth quarter in repurchase, and the total mortgage repurchase reserve now stands at $106 million.  Going forward, we'll continue to carefully monitor changes in the dynamics of this risk.  Going forward overall, our operating expenses should come down as we focus on the efficiency initiatives. But the environmental costs, which totaled around $250 million for all of 2009, are expected to remain sizable and volatile in 2010.Flip over to Page 10, our balance sheet showed some positive trends this quarter. National Specialty Lending's loan portfolio shrank by another $500 million or so in the fourth quarter. Our consolidated average core deposits increased 3% linked quarter. And during the fourth quarter, we repatriated more than $400 million in wealth management customer deposits back on to our balance sheet.Our consolidated net interest margin expanded, again, five basis points to 3.19% from the third quarter, as the average rate paid on core deposits decreased 11 bps and loan yields improved nine basis points from last quarter. Notably, our weighted average cost of deposits is below 100 basis points now, 92 basis points in the fourth quarter. And our wholesale funding has been reduced further. In fact, it's been reduced by about $4 billion over the past 12 months.  We believe the balance sheet in total is most likely near its low point, and our balance sheet mix is asset-sensitive, which we believe gives us flexibility in the current rate environment and benefits us if rates rise.So to wrap up, I think the challenges are certainly not behind us, but we believe there were a number of encouraging underlying fourth quarter trends. As Bryan said, we believe we're entering 2010 with a strong balance sheet. We're making progress in building our core businesses. We've strengthened our net interest margin. We're identifying and realizing productivity and efficiency benefits. And as Greg is now going to talk to you about, credit quality is improving, though related costs are likely to remain elevated in 2010. With that, I'll turn it over to Greg.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Our asset quality comments start on Slide 12. As an overarching statement, asset quality improvements are gaining some positive momentum at First Horizon, as most portfolios show signs of stabilization and progress of winding-down the Nation
componenttext: Good morning. Our asset quality comments start on Slide 12. As an overarching statement, asset quality improvements are gaining some positive momentum at First Horizon, as most portfolios show signs of stabilization and progress of winding-down the National portfolio continues.Net charge-offs decreased again in the quarter to $183 million. The decrease is driven by lower losses in the consumer portfolios, including one-time close mortgage and home equity lending. Commercial charge-offs were flat overall, with lower C&I [Commercial & Industrial] losses offset by higher commercial real estate losses.The loan loss reserve declined $48 million, driven primarily by a decrease in reserves held for the one-time close portfolio due to better-than-expected disposition results. The level of required reserves for the Residential CRE [Commercial Real Estate] and home equity portfolios also decreased in the fourth quarter. At 4.95% of total loans, our reserve remains high relative to peers, but down somewhat from the 5.1% coverage in the previous quarter. Provision expense totaled $135 million, a $50 million decrease from the third quarter and the second consecutive quarter of meaningfully-lower provision expense. Turning to Slide 13, we experienced a third consecutive quarter of non-performing asset reduction, with NPAs down 14% on a linked-quarter basis. Non-performing loan inflows slowed significantly, while dispositions continue to increase and execute at close to carrying value. NPL levels were down significantly in the one-time close in Residential CRE books and down marginally in the C&I and Income CRE portfolio.ORE balances were up $13 million to $114 million. This increase was expected and should be expected in future quarters, as some portion of non-performing loans inevitably cycle through foreclosure process. We continue to focus on minimizing the average age of our ORE inventory and keeping carrying values current, as evidenced by our valuation adjustments. Single-asset dispositions continue to be made at or close to carrying value. With respect to distressed loan and ORE management in 2010, we will continue to balance the dual goals of decreased problem assets while making the best economic decisions for our shareholders.I'll quickly go through the trends by portfolio, beginning on Slide 14 with Income CRE. As expected, charge-offs were up from last quarter to $28 million. While some charge-off activity was associated with new non-performing loans, a significant portion was related to adjusting values on previously-identified problems. Income CRE non-performers were down marginally in the quarter. And the increase in accruing delinquency is influenced by one larger transaction. Reserves are flat compared to the third quarter after being increased substantially in prior quarters.We expect Income CRE to remain challenging for the next couple of years, with elevated levels of problem assets, reserves and charge-offs, but with a risk profile less severe than we are realizing now on the Residential CRE portfolio. We feel we are managing this portfolio proactively and have its credit risk profile properly assessed and adequately reserved for. Moving on to Slide 15, we continue to see signs of stabilization in the overall C&I portfolio. Delinquencies declined 29 basis points and non-performing loans declined 23 basis points. Excluding the bank and TRUP (sic) TruPS [Trust Preferred Securities] exposures, we saw an improvement in the weighted average risk rate in munis TRupS [ph], which resulted in incrementally-lower required reserves.  C&I charge-offs totaled $21 million for the quarter, $23 million lower than last quarter. The decrease in charge-offs was greater than our expectations due to the fact that no losses were taken on the TRUPS or other bank exposures in the quarter.On to Slide 16, we continue to focus significant attention on our Trust Preferred loan portfolio, on loans extended to bank holding companies and on other loans secured by bank stock. Due to distressed financial services industry is under, the risk profile of loans in these portfolios is assessed quarterly to ensure proper risk management and the adequacy of reserves. Here, we disclosed the risk profile of these portfolios and the level of reserves or low com associated with them. Balances remained flat from last quarter. We increased reserves for this book again this quarter in response to negative-grade migration and management's qualitative assessment of the state of the industry.Moving on Slide 17, home equity balances were $6.9 billion for the fourth quarter. Our core portfolio remained flat at $2.6 billion, and our National portfolio continued in slow runoff, decreasing $171 million to $4.3 billion. Charge-offs decreased modestly from last quarter to $52 million, and we decreased home equity reserves by $15 million in response to incrementally-lower balances and delinquency trends moderating. We expect home equity losses to remain flat to recent quarterly results in the first half of 2010 and decrease slightly in the second half of the year. The home equity portfolio has consistently performed better than market expectations due to the higher-quality characteristics of this portfolio.  We expect this stable performance to continue, barring any further severe economic shocks.On to Slide 18, you can see the National Wind-Down portfolio has remained on track. Again, this quarter, balances declined almost $500 million and required reserves decreased by $65 million. OTC balances were down $130 million from last quarter and now stand at $230 million with negligible undrawn commitments remaining. Recall that two years ago, one-time close commitments were $3 billion. OTC charge-offs were down $11 million and reserves decreased $48 million but remained substantial at 27% of loans.National Residential CRE balances were down $137 million from last quarter to $340 million. Charge-offs for the entire Residential CRE book were above expectations due to the continued write-down of non-performing loans as a result of decline in collateral values, same issue that was discussed earlier in our Income CRE commentary. Permanent Mortgage balances remained relatively flat for the quarter despite some migration of completed OTC loans to this book. While delinquency was up slightly, we have seen positive trends in entry-level lower [ph] rates and see deterioration in this portfolio moderating. Charge-offs were down for the quarter. However, we built reserves due to increases in observed severities in problem-asset dispositions and the impact extended foreclosure periods are having on loss content.  We are proud of the progress we have made winding-down the National construction portfolios and expect most of these loans to be worked through in 2010.  On Slide 19, fourth quarter on aggregate was a little better than expected from a charge-off perspective but about as expected from a reserve perspective, although there was some variation from expectations at the sub-portfolio level. Overall, 2009 played out as we thought it might last January.  Assuming current economic trends continue, we expect the further trend of lower losses and lower required reserves and aggregate throughout 2010. We do see the possibility of more quarter-to-quarter volatility in results, however, as the portfolios most at risk, TruPS, bank exposures and Income CRE, tend to be less granular than the other segments of our portfolio. Now I'll turn it back to Bryan for some final comments.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. In 2009, we made considerable headway in repositioning First Horizon, enabling us to refocus on our core businesses and strengthen our business model.  Thanks to the hard work of our team, we were able to reduce risk in our balance sheet, ge
componenttext: Thanks, Greg. In 2009, we made considerable headway in repositioning First Horizon, enabling us to refocus on our core businesses and strengthen our business model.  Thanks to the hard work of our team, we were able to reduce risk in our balance sheet, get ahead of our credit challenges and improve our capital and liquidity.  In 2010, we expect continued progress towards reaching sustained profitability. But as BJ said, the challenges aren't over. The economic recovery is likely to be slow, and environmental and credit costs are anticipated to remain elevated, although below 2009's level. Nonetheless, we anticipate a gradually-improving bottom line as we move through the year, assuming the economic recovery remains intact. We have more work to do, deepening customer relationships, building on our core businesses and improving our operating efficiency. But longer term, I'm increasingly confident in First Horizon's ability to consistently deliver solid, high-quality returns for shareholders. Thank you. Now, operator, we'll open the call for questions please.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Brian Foran with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Brian Foran with Goldman Sachs.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I ask about the mortgage rep [repurchase] and warranty reserves and any -- I realize you're limited maybe on what you can say, given some of the stuff is in negotiations, but any metrics you can give on sizing up the total potential liability or what
componenttext: Can I ask about the mortgage rep [repurchase] and warranty reserves and any -- I realize you're limited maybe on what you can say, given some of the stuff is in negotiations, but any metrics you can give on sizing up the total potential liability or what are the specific areas of weakness and any kind of rescission rates? And then also, there was a press release from the HUD [Housing and Urban Development] out yesterday on FHA [Federal Housing Administration] rescissions. And I guess the question with there would be, is any of that activity already reflected in your reserve or would that be incremental going forward?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, it's BJ. I'll take that one. Mortgage repurchase, we obviously look at that closely every month actually, instead of for the quarter. What we saw this quarter was higher inflows into the pipeline, so higher put-backs from our investors, as well as
componenttext: Brian, it's BJ. I'll take that one. Mortgage repurchase, we obviously look at that closely every month actually, instead of for the quarter. What we saw this quarter was higher inflows into the pipeline, so higher put-backs from our investors, as well as slower resolutions coming out of the pipeline. So we've done a pretty good job. We have a very experienced team that works these pretty hard, but moving up through the pipeline does take a little bit longer. And so with that, we had a larger pipeline. And therefore, looking at both historical loss, as well as what we think inherent loss could be from those, that's how we set the reserve. And we thought it was appropriate to increase the reserve fairly substantially for that. In terms of the metrics that we look at, we obviously look at the pipeline growth. We look at what's called the rescission rate, which is when a repurchase request is made of us, how often do we put it back to the investors so to speak. That has remained fairly steady. And we obviously look at the severity of loss coming back in, which has come down a little bit over the last couple of quarters but not alarmingly. So really, most of our repurchase reserve increase was related to the increase in the pipeline. Looking at it, we feel like we've done a very good job working the repurchase. We've done a very good job of building the reserve and being appropriately reserved for it. If you look at our numbers, we actually had actual charge-offs and losses of about $17 million or about $5 million a month, and we have a repurchase reserve of $106 million. So we feel like we have a pretty good coverage on it.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Bryan Jordan. I'll add to BJ's comment. We built the reserves substantially, as we pointed out. The thing that makes all of this difficult to estimate is there's no precedent or history that you can really rely on. I think it's important to
componenttext: Brian, this is Bryan Jordan. I'll add to BJ's comment. We built the reserves substantially, as we pointed out. The thing that makes all of this difficult to estimate is there's no precedent or history that you can really rely on. I think it's important to note that we originated our last mortgage in August of 2008. And so, yes, to some point, that tail runs through. We've got about 16, 18 months of period where we've seen it come through the portfolio through the pipeline. So we feel like we're getting closer. But again, this is an area where, without precedence, it's very difficult to estimate the inherent loss.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could broaden the question to the other environmental cost, I mean, I guess clearly they're a lagging indicator and it's positive that NPAs in turn seem to have peaked. Is there any historical perspective there in terms of what the -- if NPAs have in
componenttext: If I could broaden the question to the other environmental cost, I mean, I guess clearly they're a lagging indicator and it's positive that NPAs in turn seem to have peaked. Is there any historical perspective there in terms of what the -- if NPAs have in fact peaked, how many quarters or years would you expect environmental costs to remain elevated before those start consistently coming down as well?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, it's BJ again. I think what we expect is that commensurate with asset quality improving, we expect those environmental costs to come down. If you look at where we think our long-term targets are for annualized provision based on the risk that we'd
componenttext: Brian, it's BJ again. I think what we expect is that commensurate with asset quality improving, we expect those environmental costs to come down. If you look at where we think our long-term targets are for annualized provision based on the risk that we'd want on our balance sheet, it will take several years, three, four years, for us to fully work through all of the elevated environmental costs that we have. But again, we think that it incrementally steps down over time as our asset quality improves.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bob Patten with Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bob Patten with Morgan Keegan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of expense lines and what would you think the run rate is going to be, obviously, comp expenses were down a lot in the fourth quarter. They can't stay down in this level, but you identified another $100 million, of which 2/3 were already -- and r
componenttext: In terms of expense lines and what would you think the run rate is going to be, obviously, comp expenses were down a lot in the fourth quarter. They can't stay down in this level, but you identified another $100 million, of which 2/3 were already -- and run rate it fourth quarter '09. So how should we think about core expenses outside of what Bryan was talking about for the environmental cost?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's BJ. I think you should look at those expense efficiencies that we talked about, the $100 million, as being in the run rate for 2010. And going forward, we expect to implement the rest and see a full impact of that $100 million going forward into
componenttext: Bob, it's BJ. I think you should look at those expense efficiencies that we talked about, the $100 million, as being in the run rate for 2010. And going forward, we expect to implement the rest and see a full impact of that $100 million going forward into 2011. So if you kind of -- I think we gave you what our entire 2009 environmental costs were, about $250 million or so. So you kind of look at that, you look at our normalized run rates, less $100 million going forward into 2011, and that should give you a good idea of it.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Since BofA and the capital raises, we saw you guys in December, what has changed in your thinking around TARP? Have you talked with your regulators? Is there any view that has changed or maybe more thoughtful in terms of how you would maybe exit that in t
componenttext: Since BofA and the capital raises, we saw you guys in December, what has changed in your thinking around TARP? Have you talked with your regulators? Is there any view that has changed or maybe more thoughtful in terms of how you would maybe exit that in the late 2010 or whatever?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I hope we're being thoughtful about it. We've spent a lot of time trying to follow what's unfolded in the last month and a half, and we're very in tuned with what's going on there. We are in the process of discussing internally how we work with our regula
componenttext: I hope we're being thoughtful about it. We've spent a lot of time trying to follow what's unfolded in the last month and a half, and we're very in tuned with what's going on there. We are in the process of discussing internally how we work with our regulators through what we consider a process to evaluate the right time and the right way to repay TARP. I would hope that during 2010, we can make significant progress during there, in that regard. So we are evaluating it, we're going to work with our regulators as appropriate, and I hope we make significant progress this year.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Usdin with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Usdin with Bank of America.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guys have clearly made some great progress kind of turning the corner on charge-offs and the allowance. I was wondering if you can help us. I'm trying to understand a little bit about, just about directional and magnitude, now that we've seen some of
componenttext: You guys have clearly made some great progress kind of turning the corner on charge-offs and the allowance. I was wondering if you can help us. I'm trying to understand a little bit about, just about directional and magnitude, now that we've seen some of these categories really starting to shrink as far as the national stuff, can you give us just a little bit of granularity in terms of how to understand the kind of progression from here as far as runoff versus core charge-offs, and then kind of the moving parts within the allowance as you continue to work that down as you go forward?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken, this is Greg, I'll take a stab at that. And I think it would be helpful to be on Slide 19, which we try again to give a view of what we expect in this time, really more a year-to-year view. We'd like to say that we'll see sequential quarter-to-q
componenttext: Yes, Ken, this is Greg, I'll take a stab at that. And I think it would be helpful to be on Slide 19, which we try again to give a view of what we expect in this time, really more a year-to-year view. We'd like to say that we'll see sequential quarter-to-quarter decreases in charge-offs and reserves, and that would be what we'd expect. The issue with 2010 is that we're dealing with portfolios. The ones that are most under stress now tend to be less granular than the balance of our portfolio. So from a quarter-to-quarter basis, we could have a surprise in one direction or the other better than expected or worse than expected. But we think if we drew a trend line through 2010, it would be a regression line that decreased quarter-to-quarter through the year. I don't -- again, we said this last quarter, we'll say it again this quarter, I think the improvement we'll see will be incremental quarter-to-quarter. We don't see a sudden turnabout or any major release in any particular quarter, but just a steady improvement.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a second question just on the balance sheet, with regards to -- just maybe an update on balance sheet size and as far as -- obviously, we still have a good amount of the national stuff to run down, but what are you seeing as far as just loan dema
componenttext: And then a second question just on the balance sheet, with regards to -- just maybe an update on balance sheet size and as far as -- obviously, we still have a good amount of the national stuff to run down, but what are you seeing as far as just loan demand, if any at all? And do you have an expectation of the point in time at which we'll get to that kind of steady state for balance sheet size, especially the loan portfolio?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Bryan. I'll start and then BJ can pick up on it. We saw a fair amount of softness in the last half of 2009. Things -- demand sort of incrementally better in the fourth quarter. We think late fourth quarter we might have seen the stabilization
componenttext: Ken, this is Bryan. I'll start and then BJ can pick up on it. We saw a fair amount of softness in the last half of 2009. Things -- demand sort of incrementally better in the fourth quarter. We think late fourth quarter we might have seen the stabilization point in demand. We'd expect that in the Banking business, we've essentially bottomed out in terms of the loan portfolio. We expect to see, based on demand, a little bit of growth in the first quarter. But it is still fairly anemic both on the consumer side, as well as the real estate side. C&I is a little bit stronger. With respect to the aggregate balance sheet, we've seen the significant runoff and the rapid portions of the national portfolios, about $500 million decline this past quarter, a lot of that coming in our construction portfolios, income CRE, residential construction and one-time close. We'd  expect that to be more stable. So I would guess that the size of the balance sheet is going to be reasonably stable, plus or minus just $26 billion level, with a little bit of growth showing up in the bank in the early part of 2010.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to our next question from Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go to our next question from Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow on this question of magnitude on credit. If we look at the year-end allowance, we're up around $50 million from a year ago. Would it decline back to around where we were at year-end '08, around $850 million? Is that a reasonable target to a
componenttext: Just to follow on this question of magnitude on credit. If we look at the year-end allowance, we're up around $50 million from a year ago. Would it decline back to around where we were at year-end '08, around $850 million? Is that a reasonable target to assume where we could head to, or is that, when you look at the trends a bit on the optimistic side?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010

componenttext: Yes.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010

componenttext: I think our expectation is we'll do better than that. In other words, the reserve level required this time next year will be something less than the '08 level.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Less than 850 million, okay. Just a second quick question. It looks like your workout team is bringing up some capacity. Bryan, could you talk about your appetite for FDIC deals here? And should we be surprised if we get to the midpoint of this year and y
componenttext: Less than 850 million, okay. Just a second quick question. It looks like your workout team is bringing up some capacity. Bryan, could you talk about your appetite for FDIC deals here? And should we be surprised if we get to the midpoint of this year and you haven't announced any?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Steve, I would say that Greg and his team have made great progress. And at some point, they will free up some capacity. We probably got a little bit now. We feel like we're capable of participating in a FDIC transaction. I don't know that I would be
componenttext: Well, Steve, I would say that Greg and his team have made great progress. And at some point, they will free up some capacity. We probably got a little bit now. We feel like we're capable of participating in a FDIC transaction. I don't know that I would be surprised or not surprised. I think you sort of take what becomes available in terms of opportunities, and so we're going to be very focused on making sure that if we participate or don't participate, we're doing it in a thoughtful manner. So I wouldn't read too much into it one way or the other. We've got the ability to do it today. We'll think about it and look for the appropriate opportunities. But in the meantime, Greg, we'll keep the resources focused on continuing to work through the portfolio of problems that we're working on today.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the balance sheet contraction, or actually, you're comments about the balance sheet has stabilize from here. I think prior guidance at one point was something like a $23 billion, $24 billion low point in terms of the balance sheet. I heard your co
componenttext: Just on the balance sheet contraction, or actually, you're comments about the balance sheet has stabilize from here. I think prior guidance at one point was something like a $23 billion, $24 billion low point in terms of the balance sheet. I heard your comments that you said loan demand was starting to stabilize, but what was really the big driver in terms of your expectations that the balance sheet is going to stabilize $3 billion higher than where you guys had mentioned it before?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Bryan. We've -- and that maybe something that we've confused because we talked about it a lot of different ways. If you took -- and I think the way you would get to the $23 billion is if you had set the national home equity portfolio were gon
componenttext: Ken, this is Bryan. We've -- and that maybe something that we've confused because we talked about it a lot of different ways. If you took -- and I think the way you would get to the $23 billion is if you had set the national home equity portfolio were gone today, then you would be closer to that range. That's a portfolio that is going to take a little more time to work through. So we've talked -- the number that I recall is most used and is around $25 billion. So somewhere between $26 billion and $25 million is where I think it would bottom out over time. A part of that is the national portfolios, particularly the home equity is going to be a little bit slower to run off, and then when we start to see growth like we expect in the early part of 2010 in the banking portfolio, it will offset some of that. So that's sort of how we got to it. It maybe something we've confused in just the various ways we talked about it.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other question I had, just on commercial real estate. You mentioned that, I guess, lower valuations were the primary driver of the losses this quarter. Is there any change with your methodology, the way you estimate with what loss content on the CRE p
componenttext: The other question I had, just on commercial real estate. You mentioned that, I guess, lower valuations were the primary driver of the losses this quarter. Is there any change with your methodology, the way you estimate with what loss content on the CRE portfolios? I'm curious if this is something that we should expect to see continue for the next several quarters or if this was due some unusual or one-time adjustment.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Greg. No, we have not changed our methodology. In fact, we've tried to be very, very consistent to make sure that we mark things on a quarterly basis to what we think the net realizable value is. Really, the driver with what we saw here in th
componenttext: Ken, this is Greg. No, we have not changed our methodology. In fact, we've tried to be very, very consistent to make sure that we mark things on a quarterly basis to what we think the net realizable value is. Really, the driver with what we saw here in the fourth quarter was some larger properties getting reappraised and values coming in, and a lot of it was more land-related values coming in lower than would have been anticipated and going hit and taking those marks. So to the extent, appraised values, we have seen a little bit of stabilization across commercial real estate. Land continues to be an asset class that can hold some valuation surprises. We haven't changed the methodology. We continue to be diligent and take our matters from quarter-to-quarter.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I just want to talk about the net addition to nonperforming loan trends, which saw a pretty big improvement in the fourth quarter, and it was even  a much bigger improvement than the early stage delinquency trends. I'm just wondering if you could t
componenttext: First, I just want to talk about the net addition to nonperforming loan trends, which saw a pretty big improvement in the fourth quarter, and it was even  a much bigger improvement than the early stage delinquency trends. I'm just wondering if you could talk about the drivers here and how you expect this level to trend into the first half of 2010.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. Yes, I think if you get behind our numbers, the portfolios that have most contributed to nonperforming loans have been one-time close and our national res CRE portfolios and those things. As they wind down, there's less to flow in. We also ag
componenttext: Sure, Craig. Yes, I think if you get behind our numbers, the portfolios that have most contributed to nonperforming loans have been one-time close and our national res CRE portfolios and those things. As they wind down, there's less to flow in. We also again talked about stabilization we've seen in the C&I book too. So we'd anticipate that the net inflows would, at this point, continue to trend down over time. Again, it's going to -- more volatile portfolios quarter-to-quarter. There could be some changes in that, but I think, overall, we think inflows, based on our portfolio, will continue on a declining trend.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a second question, really on the potential and timing of deployment of excess capital. And not to be too forward-looking here, but the return of cash dividends and buybacks, we can all assume that it's after the repayment of TARP, but how can we thin
componenttext: Just a second question, really on the potential and timing of deployment of excess capital. And not to be too forward-looking here, but the return of cash dividends and buybacks, we can all assume that it's after the repayment of TARP, but how can we think about M&A potential? Is there any potential for you guys to look at deals in and around your footprint this year?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Bryan. The dividend question is going to be contingent upon a couple of things: One is return to profitability and two is the repayment of the CPP. With respect to deploying capital, we'll be very focused in how we deploy capital. We've got
componenttext: Craig, this is Bryan. The dividend question is going to be contingent upon a couple of things: One is return to profitability and two is the repayment of the CPP. With respect to deploying capital, we'll be very focused in how we deploy capital. We've got a strong bias that we want to do it in a smart fashion. We want to be deployed in a way that we can produce very strong returns. We've; talked about, based on our expectation, a normalized capital levels producing 15% to 20% returns. The M&A environment, in my view, is likely to be largely an FDIC-driven process for the next several quarters. I think that the regular way, the market as I would define it, would be more likely late 2010, early 2011. So I think in the meantime, we'll continue to work on growing the customer business, work on winding down these national businesses. If FDIC opportunities happen to present themselves in and around our marketplace, we will consider that. And I think the regular way markets will come back is just going to be another several quarters before we get to that point.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Rob from Matt's team. On the NIM, it continued to increase, up five basis points quarter-to-quarter, but the rate of increase is more modest than the past few quarters. So how should we think about the magnitude of NIM increases in 1Q, 2Q
componenttext: This is actually Rob from Matt's team. On the NIM, it continued to increase, up five basis points quarter-to-quarter, but the rate of increase is more modest than the past few quarters. So how should we think about the magnitude of NIM increases in 1Q, 2Q of next year? And I guess how much can continue to reduce funding costs, specifically, repricing some of your CDs?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rob, its BJ. We've been pretty pleased with what we've seen on NIM expansion throughout 2009. I think going into next year, we do see the opportunity for further improvement in the NIM, but it will probably be modest, reason being is that -- as he mention
componenttext: Rob, its BJ. We've been pretty pleased with what we've seen on NIM expansion throughout 2009. I think going into next year, we do see the opportunity for further improvement in the NIM, but it will probably be modest, reason being is that -- as he mentioned, we've gotten much improved funding costs, particularly on weighted average rate paid for deposits. We will probably see incremental improvement in that as we allow CDs to run off, and that will certainly help, but we're getting close to the point where there's just a natural floor on it. So that will be tougher to improve. We've also been pretty pleased with what we've seen on improving loan yields. But again, that takes a lot of work through the portfolio. I think now we're getting to the point where we've taken a lot of the organic steps, so to speak, to put us on the right track for sustained improved NIM. But going forward, we'll probably need a little more help from the rate environment. Meaning, as rates rise, we think that's when we'll start to see more NIM expansion over time, but until then, it will probably be much more modest than you've seen in the last couple quarters.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one quick clarification on the mortgage banking repurchase provision line item. Obviously, that jumped up this quarter and you guys have talked about that. But just looking forward, should we view that as somewhat of a deliberate true-up of that rese
componenttext: Just one quick clarification on the mortgage banking repurchase provision line item. Obviously, that jumped up this quarter and you guys have talked about that. But just looking forward, should we view that as somewhat of a deliberate true-up of that reserve this quarter and not necessarily look at that amount as a run rate over the next few quarters? And should we more look at the last couple of quarters as more of a run rate in trying to forecast earnings?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is BJ, I'll take a crack at that. No, again, I don't know if we necessarily changed quarter to quarter how we look at it. We look at historical loss rates, inherent loss rates, what's coming in to the pipeline, et cetera. So at this time, we thought
componenttext: This is BJ, I'll take a crack at that. No, again, I don't know if we necessarily changed quarter to quarter how we look at it. We look at historical loss rates, inherent loss rates, what's coming in to the pipeline, et cetera. So at this time, we thought that was the most prudent thing, was to build the reserve fairly substantially over what we have seen in the last couple quarters. As Bryan said, we haven't originated a loan for sale since third quarter of 2008. So we do think that at some point, the inflows will strive and could stop fairly rapidly. But I would be surprised if we saw that magnitude of increase unless the environment got significantly worse than where we sit today.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Jefferson Harralson with KBW.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Jefferson Harralson with KBW.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: What's the amount of the loans that you sold? Or said another way, the $106 million, what is that in basis points of the amount of loans that could come back to you?
componenttext: What's the amount of the loans that you sold? Or said another way, the $106 million, what is that in basis points of the amount of loans that could come back to you?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jefferson, this is Bryan. That's a $100 billion plus number of loans that we've sold. I commented earlier, one of the difficulties in estimating these reserves is not having any precedent form. And as BJ and I both have pointed out, we originated our last
componenttext: Jefferson, this is Bryan. That's a $100 billion plus number of loans that we've sold. I commented earlier, one of the difficulties in estimating these reserves is not having any precedent form. And as BJ and I both have pointed out, we originated our last loan in August of 2008. One of the factors that intuitively believe is that a problem that is based on a fraud or a misrep is going to surface earlier in the cycle. If something performs for an 18-month period or thereabouts, it may be something other than a fraud or a misrep. But there is strong incentive for a lot of these loans to be pushed back to the originator, particularly on a rep and warranty claim and force us to fight our way through the rescission process. So there's not a lot of good history. As BJ pointed out, we lost roughly $5 million per month in the fourth quarter of $17 million, I think was the number. We increased our reserve by about 45 million in the quarter, taking it from roughly $60 million to $106 million. That's a long way of saying there's not a lot of history, we think, that we're getting a lot of the potential volume through the pipeline in 2009, and we're not sure quite where it goes in 2010, but we'll stay on top of it and we'll continue to evaluate. It's one of those areas that's just going to involve over time.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So is that a better question to ask, what percentage of the loans have gone NPA in your buyer's portfolios, or they find it some kind of technical issue with and you're having to pay on? Is that a better way to think about that?
componenttext: So is that a better question to ask, what percentage of the loans have gone NPA in your buyer's portfolios, or they find it some kind of technical issue with and you're having to pay on? Is that a better way to think about that?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's BJ. I think most of what we see, not all, but most, are when loans are delinquent. That's when the investor will certainly put it back. So that's kind of most of the volume that we're seeing. We've seen an increase from our largest investors in
componenttext: Yes. It's BJ. I think most of what we see, not all, but most, are when loans are delinquent. That's when the investor will certainly put it back. So that's kind of most of the volume that we're seeing. We've seen an increase from our largest investors in terms of really trying to work their books to find anything that they can to put back, as Bryan said. So we're working with them and trying to size it as best as we can. One other thing I'll mention, Bryan's, to what he said about what we've originated, as you obviously know, once it's refi-ed away from the investor, we don't have further rep in warranty on that. So as we try to look at total inherent loss content, it's not quite as easy as just saying how much did we originate and so on. It's a little more than that, and we do a heck of a lot of work to try to pinpoint as best as we can, but it's as much an art as a science.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: To your point, Jefferson, if there is a loss inherent in a loan, it's likely to be pushed back to, for us, say a rep in warranty claim. And that's not just a First Horizon question, that's an industry-wide issue that we're all going through for what seems
componenttext: To your point, Jefferson, if there is a loss inherent in a loan, it's likely to be pushed back to, for us, say a rep in warranty claim. And that's not just a First Horizon question, that's an industry-wide issue that we're all going through for what seems to be the very first time in a large-scale basis.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, in terms of your comments, Greg, I think it was in terms of the commercial real estate losses where it seemed to be more related to land exposures. Can we infer from that, the non-land exposures that are actually performing maybe in line wit
componenttext: First of all, in terms of your comments, Greg, I think it was in terms of the commercial real estate losses where it seemed to be more related to land exposures. Can we infer from that, the non-land exposures that are actually performing maybe in line with your expectations, or may be a little bit better than your expectations at present?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think looking at our slides for income CRE is Slide 14. In terms of performance by category, you can see there in the bottom right, land is clearly the worst performing asset class. My comments earlier around the losses that were realized in fourt
componenttext: Matt, I think looking at our slides for income CRE is Slide 14. In terms of performance by category, you can see there in the bottom right, land is clearly the worst performing asset class. My comments earlier around the losses that were realized in fourth quarter, about 2/3 or so of the losses that we experienced were related, and that's a rough estimate, to reassessing values of existing non-performers rather than new inflows, and the larger contributor there was where there's land because the values have dropped more precipitously on that. You can see the category performance by other income CRE types, and I think we're, safe to say, we're elevated across the board. We're concerned about all of income CRE. I think where we get comfort in terms of our guidance and as the loss levels and reserve levels of 2010, is we have pretty aggressively or appropriately migrated grades down, our loans down to the grading process in 2009 and built reserves for these loans, the balances are decreasing. So we think we've got things set for a pretty stable performance in 2010 relative 2009. But again, this is a portfolio that we don't see marked improvement for the next couple of years. And I think that would be consistent with an industry view.

componenttext: The C&I growth you saw at period end and into fourth quarter was almost exclusively the mortgage warehouse line utilization, about $200 million increase. We did see sort of as an overall core C&I comment, slight uptick on line utilizations, C&I in fourth quarter, it's sort of in line with what you're hearing in the industry about rebuilding inventories. It was modest, but there was some improvement utilization.

componenttext: My first question is a clarification surrounding the reserve. Greg, since any incremental new NPL inflows will likely be lower severity, how comfortable are you and at what floor are you willing to sort of lower the reserve coverage ratio to NPLs in 2010 relative to where we've seen it over the past couple of years?

componenttext: Sure. Again, it's surrounding the reserves, I was just wondering since any net new NPL inflows will likely be on lower severity products, I was wondering how comfortable are you bleeding down your reserve coverage ratio to NPLs in 2010 from where you've been reporting it over the past couple of years?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start and Greg can pick up on it. It's going to depend on portfolios. If you look at some of these national portfolios, one-time close, we've got a reserve coverage that's 26%, 27%. And the bank trust preferred portfolio, we've got about [Audio Gap]
componenttext: I'll start and Greg can pick up on it. It's going to depend on portfolios. If you look at some of these national portfolios, one-time close, we've got a reserve coverage that's 26%, 27%. And the bank trust preferred portfolio, we've got about [Audio Gap] bank loans, we've got about 17% [Audio Gap]The construction is likely to be gone throughout 2010, so we'd expect to see those come down. I would guess that on our commercial real estate loans where we've got something like 8.6%, 8.7% reserves, they would likely remain elevated for a period of time. With the improvement we've seen in C&I and some of these other portfolios like home equity home where we reduced reserves slightly this quarter, there is a chance that they will come down throughout 2010. So as Greg said to the question earlier, we expect to see reserve levels trend down in the aggregate across 2010. And as we've said in the past, over time, we migrate back down to a reserve level that's probably in the 2% or less range.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Erika, I'll just tag on to that. I think you've probably heard us bristle before at reserves to NPLs because so much of our portfolio is real estate-dependent because of the national portfolios. And we've gone ahead and marked the loss content and ta
componenttext: Yes, Erika, I'll just tag on to that. I think you've probably heard us bristle before at reserves to NPLs because so much of our portfolio is real estate-dependent because of the national portfolios. And we've gone ahead and marked the loss content and taken the losses. So we did see that coverage ratio reserves to NPLs increase here in fourth quarter, but we still think that that's probably not, based on our portfolio, the best ratio to look at.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
