componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Horizon National Corp. Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Aarti Bowman with Investor Relations.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Please note that our press release and financial supplement, as well as the slide presentation will use this morning are posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.com. Before we begin, we need to inform you t
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Please note that our press release and financial supplement, as well as the slide presentation will use this morning are posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.com. Before we begin, we need to inform you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, which may include guidance involving significant risks and uncertainties. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those in forward-looking information. Those factors are outlined in the recent earnings press release, and more details are provided in the most current 10-Q and 10-K. First Horizon National Corp. disclaims any obligation to update any forward-looking statements that are made from time to time to reflect future events or developments. 
In addition, non-GAAP financial information may be noted in this conference call. A reconciliation of that non-GAAP information to comparable GAAP information will be provided as needed in the footnote or appendix of the slide presentation available in the Investor Relations area of our website. Listeners are encouraged to review any such reconciliations after this call. Also, please remember that this webcast on our website is the only authorized record of this call. 
This morning's speakers include our CEO, Bryan Jordan; our CFO, BJ Losch; and our Chief Credit Officer, Greg Jardine. With that, I'll turn it over to Bryan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thanks for joining the call. Second quarter's results demonstrate that the successful execution of our strategic plan is paying off. Our proactive approach to credit quality, aggressive derisking efforts and the refocus
componenttext:
Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thanks for joining the call. Second quarter's results demonstrate that the successful execution of our strategic plan is paying off. Our proactive approach to credit quality, aggressive derisking efforts and the refocus on core businesses have resulted in First Horizon's first bottom line profits since the first quarter of 2008. Income from continuing operations was $20 million, a significant turnaround both year-over-year and linked quarter. Improved credit quality was a major driver, linked quarter, provision expense decreased to $70 million, charge-offs were down 27% and NPAs declined 14%. 
We also benefited from our refocus on the Regional Banking and Capital Markets businesses as both showed good performance in the second quarter. FTN Financial remained a high return on capital business for us. Average daily revenue decline towards normalized levels, but it's still solid. Regional Bank profitability was sharply improved due to lower credit costs and higher revenue. The Regional Bank continues to demonstrate customer deposit growth, improved fee revenue and strengthening net interest margin.
Loan demand remained soft, but we've seen signs of increased borrowing activity in our Corporate Lending line of business and from mortgage warehouse lending. Additionally, the loan pipeline is improving.
We are proud of the profitability we achieved this quarter, but mindful that the economic and operating environment will remain tough near-term. We believe that the economy will continue to recover, but at a gradual pace. Higher unemployment and a weak housing market are likely to remain, restraining organic growth prospects and keeping environmental costs elevated. Against the backdrop of likely low-single digit economic growth, we expect interest rates to remain low for an extended period and we also expect loan growth to be low overall, but benefiting from our customer acquisition efforts.
And while we support financial regulatory reform, the legislation is expected to pressure industry revenue and elevate expenses. There's still a lot of unknowns, but we are already taking steps to mitigate revenue losses. The new rules are not expected to adversely affect our Capital Markets business. The elimination of Trust Preferred Securities as a source of Tier 1 capital should not materially affect our capital position. Our TRUPs account only for $300 million of Tier 1 capital or 144 basis points of our strong Tier 1 ratio of 16.8%.
Although a slow economy and regulatory reform provide uncertainty and challenges, they also provide opportunities. Opportunities that we are fully prepared to take advantage of. We have the team, the product capability, the systems and the capital. We've made significant progress in reducing our balance sheet risk and cleaning up problem loans. We've made headway in lowering operating costs and improving efficiency. Near term, modest organic growth, credit cost reduction and efficiency improvements will likely drive our bottom line improvement. I'm confident in our ability to take market share's revenue growth opportunity surface.
BJ will now take you through the financial results for the quarter, and I'll be back as we take your questions. BJ?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. Starting on Slide 5, give you an idea of our consolidated earnings view. Second quarter net income available to common shareholders was $3 million, for an EPS of $0.01, an improvement from first quarter's loss of ab
componenttext:
Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. Starting on Slide 5, give you an idea of our consolidated earnings view. Second quarter net income available to common shareholders was $3 million, for an EPS of $0.01, an improvement from first quarter's loss of about $0.12 a share. Our pretax net income was $18 million. Second quarter's results were driven by improvement in credit quality and better hedging results, partially offset by continued elevated mortgage repurchase expense.
To turn to Slide 6. Our core businesses, again, Regional Banking, Capital Markets and our Corporate segment, had a combined pretax income of $52 million in the second quarter, up from $39 million in the first. Consolidated pretax income again was $18 million. Looking at the Regional Bank, we had pretax income of $29 million compared to last quarter's loss of $5 million, reflecting a nearly 50% decrease in the Regional Bank's provision to $28 million in the second quarter. This decrease in provision was driven by stabilizing trends in the bank's core C&I portfolio. Pretax pre-provision income increased $10 million linked quarter to $57 million. Revenues were up 4% from last quarter, benefiting from higher net interest income and a seasonal rebound in NSF/OD fees. Same time, non-interest expenses declined about 1%. 
Our banker's focused on superior customer service and calling efforts paid off, as average core deposits were up 3%. Loan demand continues to be muted and average loans in the Regional Bank were down about 1% for the quarter.
On the Capital Markets side, we've had another good quarter as pretax income was $28 million. Fixed income revenues continue to normalize, declining 13% linked quarter. Our average daily revenue was down from $1.7 million in the first quarter to $1.5 million in the second. Expenses declined 7%, mostly related to those lower revenues.
In our Corporate segment, we had a pretax loss this quarter of $5 million compared to last quarter's pretax income of $11 million. As you'll remember, we had a debt repurchase gain of $17 million in the first quarter. Our Corporate NII dropped $4 million due to a decline in yield and the size of the securities portfolio combined with the changing consolidated balance sheet mix.
Our Non-Strategic segment posted a 41% increase in revenues from last quarter, reflecting positive mortgage hedging results of $44 million, primarily due to rate movements favorably affecting fair value of the MSR hedges. At the end of the second quarter, our servicing portfolio was down to about $32 billion. We believe that this is a manageable size for us, and the associated cash flow stream that it provides will give us somewhat of an offset to the mortgage repurchase expenses.
To move to Slide 7 quickly, our consolidated expenses were flat linked quarter, at about $342 million. While we continue to focus on efficiency efforts, we are still facing significant headwinds from environmental costs in our Non-Strategic segment, driven by mortgage repurchase.
If you move to Slide 8, I'll get into details a little bit more on the mortgage repurchase reserve. After flattening in the fourth quarter to the first quarter, our new requests again increased in the second, while resolutions remained flat, causing our aggregate pipeline to increase to $411 million. In the second quarter, we built the reserve to $162 million and had a mortgage repurchase provision expense of $56 million, a $15 million increase from 1Q '10 and back to levels we saw in the fourth quarter. Charge-offs remain stable with $20 million, with our rescission rates and loss severities remaining steady to prior quarters as well. Notifications of rescissions of coverage from mortgage insurers continue to increase and could present additional uncertainty in the volatility of our mortgage repurchase expenses.
Moving to Slide 9, looking at the margin. Our consolidated net interest margin remained flat at 3.19%. The margin was negatively impacted from carrying excess balances at the Fed this quarter, and the Non-Strategic portfolio also continues to be a drag on overall margin. On the bright side, the Regional Bank's net interest margin was up 14 basis points linked quarter to 5.10%, due to improve loan pricing and the lessening impact of non-accruals in our Regional Bank. In this low interest rate environment, we do expect the margin to remain somewhat stable for the remainder of this year, absent interest rate increases.
In summary, we're certainly not declaring victory as the Non-Strategic businesses continue to create near-term volatility, and we have a long road to go to meet our bonefish targets for returns and profitability. With that said, we're pleased with second quarter's progress and will continue to work diligently to sustain and improve profitability. As Bryan said, any near-term profit gains are likely to be driven by our efforts to reduce credit-related costs and expenses. And at the same time, we'll continue to work to ensure that we're fully prepared to take advantage of profitable lending and other revenue growth opportunities.
Now I'll turn the call over to Greg to discuss second quarter's improved credit results.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, BJ, and good morning to all. I'll start with Slide 11. The second quarter showed good credit metrics. Net charge-offs were $133 million, down 27% linked quarter and down 45% year-over-year. Our net charge-off ratio improved 103 basis points from l
componenttext:
Thanks, BJ, and good morning to all. I'll start with Slide 11. The second quarter showed good credit metrics. Net charge-offs were $133 million, down 27% linked quarter and down 45% year-over-year. Our net charge-off ratio improved 103 basis points from last quarter. Charge-offs were lower from reduced balances in our non-strategic construction portfolios and stabilizing trends in our core C&I portfolio. Reserves decreased $63 million, driven by reserve releases in our national res CRE, one-time close, permanent mortgage and consumer portfolios. Our early actions of identifying problem loans to get ahead of the curve with credit issues.
Moving on to Slide 12, as Bryan mentioned earlier, non-performing assets declined 14% from last quarter and were down 27% from a year ago. This is the fifth consecutive quarter of NPA decline. Second quarter decrease was primarily driven by less inflow of non-performers and fewer downgrades. Overall, non-performing trends improved in the second quarter. But going forward, the quarter-to-quarter statistics could show some volatility from inherent lumpiness in our commercial portfolios.
Our ending balance of ORE was slightly down as well in the second quarter. We will continue to have better success in asset disposition with individual transactions. We did have a small bulk sale this quarter. We will continue to evaluate opportunities to dispose of our non-strategic assets as it makes financial sense.
Now I'll go through our portfolios in detail, starting with Income CRE on Slide 13. Our Income CRE balances were $1.6 billion at second quarter or about 9% of our total loan portfolio. Charge-offs were $12 million, down $6 million from first quarter. We have approximately 1/3 of our Income CRE portfolio maturing over the next 18 months, weakening market conditions could potentially impact performance. However, stress performance could be minimized by strong sponsors and cash flows. Our reserve levels have been at 8% or higher for four quarters in this portfolio, and reserve coverage is currently 9%.
I'll discuss our C&I portfolio on Slide 14. In the second quarter, C&I had balances of $7 billion, nearly 3/4 of this balances comprise our core C&I portfolio of general commercial loans. TRUPs, bank-related and mortgage warehouse lending make up the remainder. Charge-offs in the C&I portfolio were $20 million, down $8 million from first quarter levels. As I mentioned earlier, we're seeing some stability in the core part of our C&I portfolio.
Slide 15, gives some detail on the TRUPs and bank-related loan exposures. We have $465 million in TRUPs and $137 million in bank holding company loans. We have eight TRUPs on interest deferral and one TRUP elected deferral in the second quarter. The average size of a TRUP is $9 million. Although we did not experience any charge-offs in the TRUP book this quarter, we do not expect this trend to continue. We will continue to monitor this portfolio carefully, as it will likely show volatility and will maintain a healthy reserve.
On Slide 16, you'll see that our Home Equity portfolio trends remain stable. Second quarter's charge-offs declined $5 million linked quarter to $40 million. Delinquencies were fairly stable in both our Regional Bank and Non-Strategic portfolios. We decreased reserves by about $11 million in the Home Equity portfolio. This was the second consecutive quarter that we released reserves in the Home Equity portfolios.
This quarter's reserve decrease was from a combination of lower balances, continued lower entry roll rates, lower total delinquencies and relatively flat charge-off rates. The borrower characteristics of this book remains strong. 86% of the loans were retail originated, the average refreshed FICO is 726 and we see national originations in early 2008, limiting the loss content by vintage. We expect continued stable trends in the Home Equity portfolio, assuming ongoing economic recovery as consumer delinquency and loss rates are highly correlated with unemployment rates.
Now moving to Slide 17. It shows an update on our Non-Strategic portfolios. The national Residential CRE book was down 34% from first quarter to $177 million in second quarter. As expected, we had a $4 million reserve release 2Q 2010. Permanent Mortgage balances declined 5% linked quarter to $1 billion. Charge-offs declined 46% to $15 million linked quarter. Recall, in the first quarter, much of Perm Mortgage losses were related to an acceleration of net charge-off recognition of loans in process of foreclosure. Reserves were 7% of loans. We expect flat to improving trends in this portfolio, as we've largely eliminated the one-time close portfolio, few of the remaining loans are likely to modify into the Perm Mortgage portfolio.
On Slide 18, credit quality in the second quarter was as expected. We saw positive metrics, with lower provision expense, a decline in charge-offs and non-performing assets and a reserve decrease. Over the long term, charge-off and reserve levels should continue to decline as we complete the wind down of our Construction portfolio, Home Equity and C&I should also continue their steady trends. Although we may see some quarter-to-quarter volatility with credit trends in the Commercial portfolios.
Finally, I'd like to say I'm excited in my new role as a Chief Credit Officer. I look forward to getting to know our investors, analysts and other members of our investment community. I'll turn it over to Bryan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. I feel good about how and where we're positioned for growth when the economy improves. Economic uncertainty can create opportunities, and we plan to take advantage of these opportunities. We're focused on hiring additional talent, improving
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. I feel good about how and where we're positioned for growth when the economy improves. Economic uncertainty can create opportunities, and we plan to take advantage of these opportunities. We're focused on hiring additional talent, improving processes, upgrading technology and providing great customer service. Thanks to the hard work of our employees, we are executing on our strategy to achieve our goal of effective long-term returns for our shareholders.
Operator, we'll now take questions, please.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bob Patten for Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bob Patten for Morgan Keegan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, Bryan, BJ. It really revolves around mortgage repurchase. Is there any additional color you can give us in terms of how you guys are analyzing the flow, the light at the end of the tunnel, what are the drivers here? We're seeing sort of an
componenttext: Two questions, Bryan, BJ. It really revolves around mortgage repurchase. Is there any additional color you can give us in terms of how you guys are analyzing the flow, the light at the end of the tunnel, what are the drivers here? We're seeing sort of an increase in the pipeline growth, so that's one question. And the other question is, just around the size of the balance sheet earning assets. We see cash building up. In the supplement, you see the loan pipeline kind of slowing down in terms of the runoff. Home equity, I think is a misnomer out there about the market. Can you give us some color on those two items?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's BJ. I'll start with mortgage repurchase. Obviously, we had seen a flattening from 4Q to 1Q in new requests. And then there was a pretty material increase in requests in the second quarter. At the same time, our resolutions have stayed roughly fl
componenttext: Bob, it's BJ. I'll start with mortgage repurchase. Obviously, we had seen a flattening from 4Q to 1Q in new requests. And then there was a pretty material increase in requests in the second quarter. At the same time, our resolutions have stayed roughly flat. So most of our repurchase provisioning and reserve is related to what the aggregate size of the pipeline is. We know that we've got to get through these portfolios and get some more resolutions. So we expect to see more resolutions, which will then lead to more charge-offs and at some point, a flattening of the reserves. Now I think, it's important to keep in mind that this is obviously still an issue for us and the industry, but we ceased originations in August of 2008. So there's going to be a finite point at which our volumes start to slow. And so, we're watching this very closely. We feel like we're well reserved, and we'll always be as proactive as we can on getting through it as quickly as we can. On your second piece, the cash buildup. I think what we had was, in the second quarter, a significant dollar balance of excess reserves at the Fed. I think with the volatility in the markets, particularly of what was going on in Europe and so on, we didn't see a great entry point to buy anything into our investment securities portfolio. We will look for ways to put a little bit of money to work there, particularly if we still see loan growth being muted. We've obviously rather put it to work for customers, but we're going to try to do a little bit of both going into the second half of the year. Third piece, I think, was the level of earning assets, which stayed roughly flat at $26 billion. And what I think we've all said before is, that we do think that it flattens out anywhere between $25 billion and $26 billion for our company. As the national strategics wind off, we do think that over the next couple of quarters, we could see some modest growth in the Regional Bank that could partially or wholly offset that. So we feel like we're bottoming out around this number.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, this is Bryan. I'll add to BJ's comment. I've got a lot of confidence in our ability to put earning assets on the balance sheet at the appropriate time. As I mentioned in the prepared comments, we're starting to see some pick up in loan demand. I fee
componenttext: Bob, this is Bryan. I'll add to BJ's comment. I've got a lot of confidence in our ability to put earning assets on the balance sheet at the appropriate time. As I mentioned in the prepared comments, we're starting to see some pick up in loan demand. I feel good about the pipelines for new or incremental credit that we're seeing today. I think we're seeing a lot of very positive signs in customer activity and in customer acquisition. But I'd say loan demand, on the whole, is still reasonably low. It is not all that strong. And I would also add that the market is becoming a little bit more competitive in terms of the loan demand that's out there, particularly on the C&I side. So I'm pretty confident in our ability to grow earning assets. There'll be plenty of opportunities. I mentioned that a couple of times in the prepared remarks. I think there are going to be a lot of opportunities that come out of all the changes going on from a financial regulatory reform, coupled with a lower growth, low interest rate environment. They're going to be tough to find, but we're going to look for them and we're going to put capital to work. And then to re-emphasize BJ's point, the real rapid decline in our national portfolios is behind us. The Construction portfolios, which two and a half years ago, totaled over $4 billion today, totaled something in the neighborhood of $250 million. The Home Equity portfolio is running off at a very slow rate and as Greg said, performing well. So I think, as BJ said, we'll see our balance sheet bottoming somewhere in this $26 billion, $25 billion range.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking at some of the indicators of future credit quality trends, they really -- I thought all look pretty good with delinquencies really showing improvement in a lot of places, inflows, non-accruals down a lot. My question was on Income CRE, howeve
componenttext: Just looking at some of the indicators of future credit quality trends, they really -- I thought all look pretty good with delinquencies really showing improvement in a lot of places, inflows, non-accruals down a lot. My question was on Income CRE, however, which showed some early signs of improvement but your guidance on the charge-offs side is still pretty conservative, especially for the back half of this year. I'm just wondering if you could help us kind of reconcile this and maybe talk about what you're seeing on the Income CRE side?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Greg Jardine. I think there's a couple of things to look at. One is, just overall, what's going on in that particular industry. And we're beginning and well into maturity cycles, not just within our portfolio, but within portfolios in the C
componenttext: Craig, this is Greg Jardine. I think there's a couple of things to look at. One is, just overall, what's going on in that particular industry. And we're beginning and well into maturity cycles, not just within our portfolio, but within portfolios in the CMBS market and other banks as well. So with that, in the different types of properties that we have, we'd expect to see some continued pressure there. 60% of our book was originated in '05 through '07. Those were more peak years in terms of what's happening with cap rates in the market right now. So that's why the expectation is, it will be nothing like the Res CRE. But it will be a disturbed portfolio. We've got, we believe that we're mitigated in many ways, but we do believe that there'll be some pressure within that, depending -- hospitality is one right now, where we have no NPLs, and I would expect we might see NPLs within that particular part of our portfolio as an example.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And this is really driven by, I guess, refinancing and not defaults, is that right? Because you had five years on 2005, virtually where we are now. So that -- it's really driven by the financing side of it, is that right?
componenttext: And this is really driven by, I guess, refinancing and not defaults, is that right? Because you had five years on 2005, virtually where we are now. So that -- it's really driven by the financing side of it, is that right?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. It's the refinance side of it and frankly, we have not used A/B note structures before, and there maybe a beginning of some A/B-type note structures as we go in some of those renewals, which of course, would potentially put more pressure o
componenttext: That's correct. It's the refinance side of it and frankly, we have not used A/B note structures before, and there maybe a beginning of some A/B-type note structures as we go in some of those renewals, which of course, would potentially put more pressure on charge-offs as opposed to reserves.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Foran with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Foran with Goldman Sachs.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the rep [repurchase] and warranty, and I apologize if I missed it. Have you given a breakdown of requests between GSEs and mortgage insurers? And if you haven't, can you talk to the issue, is the mix changing at all or is it fairly steady?
componenttext: On the rep [repurchase] and warranty, and I apologize if I missed it. Have you given a breakdown of requests between GSEs and mortgage insurers? And if you haven't, can you talk to the issue, is the mix changing at all or is it fairly steady?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, it's BJ. All of the actual requests come from the -- the vast majority come from GSEs. The fewer of the request comes from privates, but the vast majority from GSEs. The MIs [mortgage insurers] don't actually make a direct request to us. They indic
componenttext: Brian, it's BJ. All of the actual requests come from the -- the vast majority come from GSEs. The fewer of the request comes from privates, but the vast majority from GSEs. The MIs [mortgage insurers] don't actually make a direct request to us. They indicate their intent to drop MI coverage and then the GSEs at that point can make a request back to us on a repurchase. So that's why we watch MI rescissions very closely, because they're a leading indicator of potential request back to us through the GSEs. Right now, in our pipeline, we would estimate something, I believe, in the range of 40% to 45% of the pipeline is related to MI rescissions.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the comments, Bryan, you made on C&I, I guess the two questions. One, on the growth side, is it more new customer demand or is it more existing customer starting to draw down on their line? And then secondly, when you say pricing is becoming m
componenttext: And then on the comments, Bryan, you made on C&I, I guess the two questions. One, on the growth side, is it more new customer demand or is it more existing customer starting to draw down on their line? And then secondly, when you say pricing is becoming more competitive, can you give us a sense may be where it was six months ago, or where it is now in terms of typical yields or spreads you're earning?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're seeing -- look, talk about the demand first. We're seeing a little more demand in the large corporate side, and the pipelines are building in a number of different areas, everything from large corporate and commercial real estate to some of the
componenttext: Yes, we're seeing -- look, talk about the demand first. We're seeing a little more demand in the large corporate side, and the pipelines are building in a number of different areas, everything from large corporate and commercial real estate to some of the -- actually, in some of the areas of the consumer portfolio. We're seeing a good mixture of new customers and a mixture of increased borrowings from existing customers. And the pipeline reports that I was looking at earlier this week was just incremental demand from existing customers or new customers, and they appear to be building very, very nicely. I talked a little bit about pricing and structure. We are starting to see spreads tighten a little bit, particularly in the C&I space. That's really a function of, I think, lower loan demand and everybody looking for good opportunities in a market with low loan demand. I commented on structure. We're starting to see some degradation or movement towards later-cycle types of structures in the C&I portfolio. And that's not so much the larger banks, it tends to come from the smaller competitors in the marketplace. So as a general observation, C&I, in particular, pricing and structure, has come under a little bit of pressure here in the last, call it, two and half months. Greg, I don't know if you had...

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that, I agree with that Bryan. Just overall, I'd say that what we see in terms of in different segments, the corporate segment has a little bit more demand than the commercial segment right now, and then business banking kind of follows that. And ther
componenttext: No, that, I agree with that Bryan. Just overall, I'd say that what we see in terms of in different segments, the corporate segment has a little bit more demand than the commercial segment right now, and then business banking kind of follows that. And there's actually some strategic opportunities in CRE, went very well. Structured loans, lot of equity, good structure, so we're not -- there's some opportunities there.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Alexopoulos from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Alexopoulos from JPMorgan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bryan, from the current level of provision, should we expect to see continued declines for the rest of the year? Or given your macro comments, are we reaching a point where you could see up-and-down volatility from here?
componenttext: Bryan, from the current level of provision, should we expect to see continued declines for the rest of the year? Or given your macro comments, are we reaching a point where you could see up-and-down volatility from here?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I look to Greg to back me up on this. It's hard to pin the tail on what quarter-to-quarter provisions are likely to be. I still expect that provision levels would trend down over the course of the year and in the next year. There may be some volatility ar
componenttext: I look to Greg to back me up on this. It's hard to pin the tail on what quarter-to-quarter provisions are likely to be. I still expect that provision levels would trend down over the course of the year and in the next year. There may be some volatility around it, but I don't expect it as I sit here today.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In my prepared remarks, I would say over the long term, we'd see it go down because it could bounce from one quarter to another. But overall, the trends are definitely going down.
componenttext: Yes. In my prepared remarks, I would say over the long term, we'd see it go down because it could bounce from one quarter to another. But overall, the trends are definitely going down.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: BJ, in your response to Bob's earlier question on the repurchase provision, you said at some point, you reach a finite point where I guess that would drop off quite a bit. What's the lag time here? And how long until we reach that point?
componenttext: BJ, in your response to Bob's earlier question on the repurchase provision, you said at some point, you reach a finite point where I guess that would drop off quite a bit. What's the lag time here? And how long until we reach that point?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your guess is as good as mine, Steve. I think my point was, since we stopped originating in August of '08, we're not adding any more loans that could then ultimately be repurchased or requested of us years later, and so we haven't originated a loan in ove
componenttext: Your guess is as good as mine, Steve. I think my point was, since we stopped originating in August of '08, we're not adding any more loans that could then ultimately be repurchased or requested of us years later, and so we haven't originated a loan in over two years, almost, or just under two years. So I guess just my point was, that we see 60% of the requests today in the '07 vintage, and so we think at some point, that's going to stop for us. And we're going to have to continue to work through the resolutions, and we're going to be pass this. I don't know when that is, but hopefully, we get there sooner rather than later.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Bryan. I'll add that this is an area that the industry and we, in particular, don't have a lot of history with. This is a really a first time through a lot of this for most of the industry. And this is a little bit, maybe, blind intuition i
componenttext: Steve, this is Bryan. I'll add that this is an area that the industry and we, in particular, don't have a lot of history with. This is a really a first time through a lot of this for most of the industry. And this is a little bit, maybe, blind intuition inappropriately, but if you think about what's happened since August of '08, in particular, because that's when we cut off origination in that business, you've gone through a 30-year high in unemployment, you've gone through a historic drop in real estate prices. And one of the things that we believe is that with those external market dynamics, if there are a problems or fraudulent loans in the portfolio, they're going to default and come to the surface reasonably fast. So we think that it'll build as it has, and at some point, it will turn and start to drop off just based on those dynamics. But again, this is an area where there aren't a lot of good historical things to look at, and so we're working our way through it, trying to gather as much information as we possibly can. And as BJ pointed out in his prepared comments, trying to build adequate and conservative reserve for what we think the risk in repurchases in the loss in the pipeline is.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the NPA sales? I mean I know you mentioned you have a small bulk sale, but obviously want to do it on individual basis if you can, presumably due to their pricing. But it means the market for bulk sale is coming back? And k
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the NPA sales? I mean I know you mentioned you have a small bulk sale, but obviously want to do it on individual basis if you can, presumably due to their pricing. But it means the market for bulk sale is coming back? And kind of what your outlook there? I mean, are we going to reach a point where risk tolerance is actually sufficient, such that you expect the bulk sale market to open up and hence, NPA balances to fall a little more substantially? Or is this a slow grind as you just keep working through it on individual basis?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Greg, I'll take a shot at that. Yes, I would not say that the bulk sale market has opened up. This was a very small one. It just happened to work. We still see much better execution with single transaction than bulk sale. We'd say, if anythin
componenttext: Yes, this is Greg, I'll take a shot at that. Yes, I would not say that the bulk sale market has opened up. This was a very small one. It just happened to work. We still see much better execution with single transaction than bulk sale. We'd say, if anything, if it had been totally frozen from, or at least, our observations of what the economics look like, it might have a couple of drips off of the ice. So it's still frozen, but it's beginning to maybe thaw just a hair. I don't see that market, at least near term, becoming exceptionally good, so I think we'll just continue to kind of grind away, at least, from what I can see at this point in time.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other question I had was just on your MSR portfolio. Just remind us your plans here, I mean obviously you brought it down to, what was it, $32 billion. But you may had comment to actually want to use this as an offset against the mortgage repurchase e
componenttext: The other question I had was just on your MSR portfolio. Just remind us your plans here, I mean obviously you brought it down to, what was it, $32 billion. But you may had comment to actually want to use this as an offset against the mortgage repurchase expenses? I mean, have we reached a stable point with the MSR portfolio that you're not going to be pursuing sales from here?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Bryan. We clearly brought it down significantly, and that's been part of what we've done over the last couple of years. It was over $100 billion when we exited the mortgage business, and today, as you said, it's about $30 billion. We think wi
componenttext: Ken, this is Bryan. We clearly brought it down significantly, and that's been part of what we've done over the last couple of years. It was over $100 billion when we exited the mortgage business, and today, as you said, it's about $30 billion. We think with the valuation that we've placed on it or that the fair values that are placed on the portfolio that we have a $30 billion. The characteristics of it, the performance characteristics, we think that these levels are pretty attractive returns on it in terms of an earning asset. And we might still have some smaller sales, but we're not going to be all that aggressive, get very aggressive at all in looking for opportunities to sell it. It does provide some offset to some of the costs of the mortgage business, and it is attractively valued earning asset at this point. It will be in attrition state. It will wind down over time. We're not adding to it, but we're not going to be proactively trying to sell it just because we're aggressive.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, if you could give a little color on the temporary increase in the trading loans? You mentioned, I think in the release, that these are expected to be sold in third quarter. If you could just give a little color on that. I apologize if you already tou
componenttext: One, if you could give a little color on the temporary increase in the trading loans? You mentioned, I think in the release, that these are expected to be sold in third quarter. If you could just give a little color on that. I apologize if you already touched on it. And then Bryan, just if you could expound upon -- you seem pretty convinced that there are going to be opportunities. If you can kind of give a little color on, is that just near term taking market share? And how do you feel about the subject of acquisitions? I know we've always talked in prior quarters about FDIC deals, but now we've seen a few live bank deals start to occur. And what's your opinion on the timing of when attractive ones are going to come up on that?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, it's BJ. I'll talk to the trading assets first. In our Capital Markets business, we have a group called Capital Assets that does loan sale solicitations [ph] (55:52)and work across the industry. And so they had a couple of transactions that happene
componenttext: Kevin, it's BJ. I'll talk to the trading assets first. In our Capital Markets business, we have a group called Capital Assets that does loan sale solicitations [ph] (55:52)and work across the industry. And so they had a couple of transactions that happened in the second quarter that just crossed the quarter, and they'll be moving through in the third quarter. So that cost is just a temporary increase at period end in the second quarter, so you should see the trading assets come back down to more normal levels in the third quarter. Bryan?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, with respect to opportunities, I think in the broad categories you described, I think there are opportunities in both. I think in the very near term, we're working aggressively in customer acquisition. I think we're doing a good job. I'm encouraged
componenttext: Kevin, with respect to opportunities, I think in the broad categories you described, I think there are opportunities in both. I think in the very near term, we're working aggressively in customer acquisition. I think we're doing a good job. I'm encouraged by what I see our bankers accomplishing in and winning new customer business, and I feel good about our opportunities there. Longer term and you pointed out, there has started to be signs, early signs of consolidation in the industry. I still think that the industry is going to go through a consolidation phase. I think it's probably a multiyear phase, call it, four- or five-year phase. As I described in the prepared, the opening comments, we think that the environment is going to be a reasonably difficult operating environment, reasonably low growth in the economy, low interest rates, a lot of change from a regulatory perspective, need to get more capital in the industry. All of that, in some sense, sets up for some amount, if not a significant amount, of consolidation in the industry, and so we think there'll be opportunities, whether they be FDIC assisted or a regular way. We're going to be patient. We're going to try to be targeting. We're going to try to put the capital to work in an effective long-term fashion, where we can build out the operating model we have that I think has been so successful in building market share and producing returns in the state of Tennessee on a broader basis, in Tennessee and then in contiguous markets. So yes, I think there'll be opportunities for consolidation. I'm just not sure at what point.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tony Davis with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tony Davis with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess because of the compression, Bryan, and that you're seeing in C&I spreads, you've identified CRE, asset-based lending as two areas that you'd like to look at more aggressively going forward. I just wondered if you have begun to make new commitments
componenttext: I guess because of the compression, Bryan, and that you're seeing in C&I spreads, you've identified CRE, asset-based lending as two areas that you'd like to look at more aggressively going forward. I just wondered if you have begun to make new commitments in CRE, and where you are in terms of the asset-based portfolio today. What's the size of receivables or the stay out for whatever you have in place?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, both businesses, we are seeing opportunities in them. The asset-based businesses has probably got, I would characterize, is more competitive in terms of the competitive dynamics around. You've got a lot of change. People getting in and people getting
componenttext: Yes, both businesses, we are seeing opportunities in them. The asset-based businesses has probably got, I would characterize, is more competitive in terms of the competitive dynamics around. You've got a lot of change. People getting in and people getting out of that business. We are seeing opportunities to grow that. Steve Hawkins and our team do a really good job of knowing their customers and building the business and building long-term relationships, and so we are seeing progress there. Commercial real estate, as Greg commented earlier, the deals, the opportunities that we are seeing in the pipeline are, I would say, very strong deals. A lot of equity in these deals, very seasoned, very well-capitalized borrowers, and that market is probably not as competitive as some others because of concentrations around the industry. It hasn't been as competitive, so we think there are opportunities in both. We think that over the course of the remainder of 2010, we have the opportunity to close a fair number of deals. Greg, I don't know what you want to add to that, if anything?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's exactly right, Bryan. The opportunities in the CRE world are very rifle shot, but they are a very extremely strong deals, and I think it is partly, as Bryan said, it's the competitive landscape and some competitors are just out of the b
componenttext: No, I think that's exactly right, Bryan. The opportunities in the CRE world are very rifle shot, but they are a very extremely strong deals, and I think it is partly, as Bryan said, it's the competitive landscape and some competitors are just out of the business.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, on a different subject, I wondered if you can chat a bit about the response you're seeing to Reg E communications. And kind of your thinking here about new checking policy, and how that might play out over the rest of the year?
componenttext: Secondly, on a different subject, I wondered if you can chat a bit about the response you're seeing to Reg E communications. And kind of your thinking here about new checking policy, and how that might play out over the rest of the year?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tony, this is Bryan, I'll start, and then BJ can help me. We received responses from, in round numbers, about half our customers at this point. We will see revenue related to Reg E decline over the second half of the year. We've got about $40 million
componenttext: Yes, Tony, this is Bryan, I'll start, and then BJ can help me. We received responses from, in round numbers, about half our customers at this point. We will see revenue related to Reg E decline over the second half of the year. We've got about $40 million annually that would be subject to Reg E in -- excuse me, in fees associated with ATM and point-of-sale debit card, NSF/OD. We think the practical diminution of that revenue in the second half of the year is probably in the $10-million range based on the response activity that we're seeing to date.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brad Gailey with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brad Gailey with KBW.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Brady. Bryan, I wanted to ask you about TARP and if $300 million of trust preferred coming out of Tier 1 changes your thoughts on repaying TARP potentially without having to raise. I know BJ, a couple of months ago, was talking about potentially payi
componenttext: It's Brady. Bryan, I wanted to ask you about TARP and if $300 million of trust preferred coming out of Tier 1 changes your thoughts on repaying TARP potentially without having to raise. I know BJ, a couple of months ago, was talking about potentially paying it off in pieces versus all at once, and I would be interested to hear the likelihood of that happening.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Bryan. It's probably too early to know quite how to react to the phaseout of trust preferreds on our capital base and how that relates to CPP repayment. I'll sort of summarize how we still think about CPP repayment. As I've said before and I
componenttext: Yes, this is Bryan. It's probably too early to know quite how to react to the phaseout of trust preferreds on our capital base and how that relates to CPP repayment. I'll sort of summarize how we still think about CPP repayment. As I've said before and I think BJ said before, we think it's a process. It's a dialogue with our regulators. We will have that dialogue with the regulators. We feel good about our capital base. Our regulators and we will talk about what's the best way to repay it, how we repay it and the timing of repaying it, and my hope still is, is that we can make significant progress in that regard during the course of 2010, essentially the second half of 2010.

Our retail organization is very, very focused in doing a very good job in terms of customer acquisition and bringing folks into the branches, so we're starting to see the momentum in the balance sheet. We're encouraged by the calling opportunities that we've had, the folks that we've got calling on the commercial side, commercial and corporate side, and overall, very pleased with the traction that Doyle Rippee and his team have created over the last 18 months or so.

componenttext: Al, it's BJ. I think what we're trying to say is that it's somewhat of an offset. Meaning, we obviously don't manage one side to match the other. But what we're saying is that we've gotten the MSR portfolio and the risk management structure around management of that, to a point where we feel good about our ability to mitigate that risk, take some of the servicing income, take some of that carry from the MSR hedge assets and have some income that offsets mortgage repurchase expense, some of the mortgage repurchase expense, ongoing every quarter. So that's kind of how we're thinking about it.

Thank you, operator. We appreciate you joining us this morning. I'm very pleased with the results of the quarter. I'm pleased with the progress we've made in repositioning the business. I think we're uniquely and very well positioned for what was likely to be a more challenging operating environment. I appreciate the hard work of our bankers, and our capital markets folks all across the organization. They've done a great job in executing. Thank you all. 
If you have any further questions, please let one of us or Aarti know. Thank you.
