componenttext: Can we just jump over to TDR for a second. Obviously, a little jump on the TDR. Is that accruing, is it not accruing? What's your thoughts on where that goes, Greg, over the next several quarters?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: The TDRs include accruing and not accruing. I would expect the TDRs to continue to increase as we work with borrowers. And obviously, it takes some time to -- as everything's performing for TDR to then remove that flag. So just where we're adding cycle an
componenttext: The TDRs include accruing and not accruing. I would expect the TDRs to continue to increase as we work with borrowers. And obviously, it takes some time to -- as everything's performing for TDR to then remove that flag. So just where we're adding cycle and working with it, and as we've got the Non-Strategic portfolio lessening, and we're working with our core franchise customers. And working through a premise with them in the cycle, I would expect that TDRs would continue to increase some. I think the other thing I comment on TDR is I think we're all expecting that between the OTC and the FAS, that we'll have some clear, fair views of how the industry used treat TDRs. Because it's a little bit opaque to everyone right now.

componenttext: I was going to add that. I think it's really determined based on where the loan is at the time of restructuring. componenttext: And then just a question to go back and it's because everybody's trying to figure out, you guys are obviously making a progress on the fundamentals. On this mortgage overhang, it is sitting there and something everyone is trying to quantify. Can you guys talk about the differences in the reps and warranties in your portfolio?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I'll just give you a couple examples, it's BJ, between with GSEs and privates. One has to do with the ownership requirements. In a private securitization, you have to have a certain level of ownership in the securities to then get the master servicer
componenttext: Bob, I'll just give you a couple examples, it's BJ, between with GSEs and privates. One has to do with the ownership requirements. In a private securitization, you have to have a certain level of ownership in the securities to then get the master servicer or the trustee to make claims requests on behalf of the investor. The second relates to the reps and warranties of what you're actually repping to on private securitization if it's more to the tapes, whereas in the GSE if it's a little bit more to the actual loans. And so there's a very broad high-level differences, so we'll see where those go.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, you talked about the reserves. The release are beginning to slow. Will you be doing 30 basis points a quarter or there above. Can you going to keep up this pace throughout the next three or four quarters and where do you stop?
componenttext: Greg, you talked about the reserves. The release are beginning to slow. Will you be doing 30 basis points a quarter or there above. Can you going to keep up this pace throughout the next three or four quarters and where do you stop?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will answer that kind of broadly. I think the point is there was rapid reserve releases as we were working through Non-Strategic. And as that gets behind us and expecting that the portfolios continues to stabilize, I think that we would look potentially
componenttext: I will answer that kind of broadly. I think the point is there was rapid reserve releases as we were working through Non-Strategic. And as that gets behind us and expecting that the portfolios continues to stabilize, I think that we would look potentially for some continued reserve releases not at the rate that we've seen before. That's going to be driven by the economy and by the individual portfolios. But much of the reserve releases were coming out of some of the Non-Strategic portfolios as well as stabilization of the Home Equity boat as well.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just putting in the order of magnitude, we said in the past, we expect that a normalized reserve will probably run under current accounting 1.5% to 2%. Today, we're at 4.22%, I think, the number was. So there's a significant amount of reserves that we thi
componenttext: Just putting in the order of magnitude, we said in the past, we expect that a normalized reserve will probably run under current accounting 1.5% to 2%. Today, we're at 4.22%, I think, the number was. So there's a significant amount of reserves that we think come down as the credit picture improves over the next couple of years.

componenttextpreview: Jon, this is Bryan. We've had, I think it's something like 60% or so of our customers who have made a decision. About half or more have opted in. It had some impact on this quarter. I think NSF/OD charges were down in the $3.5 million to $4 million range.
componenttext: Jon, this is Bryan. We've had, I think it's something like 60% or so of our customers who have made a decision. About half or more have opted in. It had some impact on this quarter. I think NSF/OD charges were down in the $3.5 million to $4 million range. We still see customers opting in. As we've said in the past, we expect that net-net, that when you work through an annual cycle, it's probably going to have something in the $10 million annualized impact on our revenue. As I said, we still see customers making decisions, we still see customers opting in. The pace has slowed a little bit here about late third quarter moving into the fourth quarter.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

componenttext: And then just one last question, you got a couple quarters of profitability back to back, and you have some clarity on capital ratios and just curious what your thinking is today on TARP, and does that capital clarity change been good for you?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that our thinking has not changed an awful lot. As I've said for the last several quarters, we'd like to make progress working our regulators to repay the TARP in a practical and sensible way. We would expect to continue our efforts in th
componenttext: Yes. I would say that our thinking has not changed an awful lot. As I've said for the last several quarters, we'd like to make progress working our regulators to repay the TARP in a practical and sensible way. We would expect to continue our efforts in that regard. And I'm hopeful that we can continue to make progress in that and repay it as that works through the process.

componenttext: Jefferson, this is Bryan. As we look at our pipeline, we're pretty encouraged by what we see in the pipeline. It's broad-based. headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: So when you think about non-performing assets, you mentioned that's moving to commercial as most of the legacy business. And when you think about how that change is affecting the NPA balances, should we be expecting sort of more of a flattening in NPA bal
componenttext: So when you think about non-performing assets, you mentioned that's moving to commercial as most of the legacy business. And when you think about how that change is affecting the NPA balances, should we be expecting sort of more of a flattening in NPA balances going forward as the Non-Strategic stuff just becomes less of a portion and you have longer commercial NPAs in there?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, generally. There's a of couple things. I think were at fulcrum point, so as the Non-Strategic is winding down, we're working with the commercial loans. One thing that will begin to happen is the upgrade process. So I think at this point in t
componenttext: Yes, I think, generally. There's a of couple things. I think were at fulcrum point, so as the Non-Strategic is winding down, we're working with the commercial loans. One thing that will begin to happen is the upgrade process. So I think at this point in time, what you're seeing within our portfolio is generally the portfolio grades improving. What happens is those that are in the criticized category are either healing or they're getting a little worst. And that's part of what we see and would expect in this part of the cycle. So as we kind of look forward, I would see NPAs kind of be around this level. And then as we continue to work with them and as we can restructure as appropriate, then we will see some upgrades out of that.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sound like it's also a driver to more of that stabilization and to some extent in the reserve ratio as well. And July might not be coming down as fast as what we would've seen otherwise.
componenttext: It sound like it's also a driver to more of that stabilization and to some extent in the reserve ratio as well. And July might not be coming down as fast as what we would've seen otherwise.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what you have seen is decent releases out of the commercial side as well, and I think that continues. But yes, I think it's -- I kind of see this as just kind of a couple of quarters as we work through this, but the NPAs will be in level and then
componenttext: I think what you have seen is decent releases out of the commercial side as well, and I think that continues. But yes, I think it's -- I kind of see this as just kind of a couple of quarters as we work through this, but the NPAs will be in level and then begin to improve.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could comment on the sustainability of the Capital Markets revenues. That was a line item that we've seen coming down the past few quarters, and it had a nice spike up this quarter. And then I just wanted to clarify on that earlier question about TDRs, is the accruing part of the TDRs, so the 50% of that $300 million, I just want to make sure I heard you right, is that included in your non-performing loans or is it not?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

Where do you stand on that today?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, this is Bryan. Let me start with the TARP and they're really closely related in some sense. As I pointed out, as we went through the prepared remarks, we've got a very a strong capital base; Tier 1 common, north of 10%, I think 10.4%; 8% tangible c
componenttext: Kevin, this is Bryan. Let me start with the TARP and they're really closely related in some sense. As I pointed out, as we went through the prepared remarks, we've got a very a strong capital base; Tier 1 common, north of 10%, I think 10.4%; 8% tangible common tangible assets. And we think that we've got a pretty strong capital base, which really enable us to do things. We want to work with our regulators as we think about how we repay the TARP to do it in a reasonable fashion and a reasonable timeframe. And we would expect to continue to work with our regulators in that regard. With respect to the M&A environment, we think that's an opportunity for us to put capital to work. We're going to be very focused and measured in how and when we'd execute on that. We want to make sure that we have the right kind of opportunity and the right kind of market, and it helps us build the franchise for the long-term. And we think there will be opportunities there. We don't feel any particular urgency around the M&A environment right now simply because we see ourselves making very good progress on the things that we're focused on day to day, growing customers, getting more productive in the way we produce revenue and more efficient in a way that we produced that revenue. And so we think we've got a lot of opportunities in a number of different avenues and stuff. We're very encouraged about what we think the next several quarters and several years hold in terms of our ability to grow the business.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: BJ, I was wondering with you talked about the reinvestment risk in the securities portfolio, how are you trying to combat that given that we do have the low interest rate environment that's going to be around for a while? And then kind of a tag on to that
componenttext: BJ, I was wondering with you talked about the reinvestment risk in the securities portfolio, how are you trying to combat that given that we do have the low interest rate environment that's going to be around for a while? And then kind of a tag on to that is how do we kind of think about the pre-payment risk in the mortgage side if you go from what is an inflated level but not really where we should be given where interest rates are at. And if we were to lose some of the servicing possibility as well as some of the national HELOC volume and also more reinvestment risk and investment portfolio, how do we handle that comps on our yields as well?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the reinvestment risk, I think I talked about that. Our yields declined about 26 basis points there. What we're trying to do with our securities portfolio is make sure that structure is right of what we're buying as opposed to looking for yields. So ou
componenttext: On the reinvestment risk, I think I talked about that. Our yields declined about 26 basis points there. What we're trying to do with our securities portfolio is make sure that structure is right of what we're buying as opposed to looking for yields. So our durations are staying very short, well probably, in the 2 ½ year range. And we want to make sure that we don't get caught upside down on the carry trade, if rates suddenly move up. So our reinvestment rates right now are right in the 2.5% range. And if you look at our maturity stacks going forward into next year and next few years, there certainly is going to be a drag if interest rates stay where they are and our reinvestment rates stay where they are. But as you know, our securities portfolio percentage of our assets is relatively small versus peers. So we think that, that drag is manageable, and we would rather not reach for yield there. We do think with the pipeline that we have on the loan side, we'd much rather put some money to work there and try to get some loan yields, which we think could happen over the next several quarters. So like I said on the NIM overall, we think it can modestly improve over the near-term. And then it will take some interest rates in general to make it move up meaningfully. In terms of the pre-payment risk on MSR, I think our CPR this quarter was 13%. So it's still very, very low. You're exactly right. If that started to increase, we'd have it running down. But as we sit here today, we think that servicing portfolio is very manageable at this size. We very much like how we're able to hedge it and the knowledge and expertise that we have around hedging it. And so we think it's a good asset for us to help us somewhat offset some of the mortgage repurchase expense that we have. So as we sit here today, we're pretty comfortable with it.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Horizon National Corp. Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Aarti Bowman.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Operator. Please note that our press release and financial supplement as well as the slide presentation we'll use this morning are posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.com.Before we begin, we need to inform you
componenttext:
Thank you, Operator. Please note that our press release and financial supplement as well as the slide presentation we'll use this morning are posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.com.
Before we begin, we need to inform you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, which may include guidance involving significant risks and uncertainties. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those in forward-looking information. Those factors are outlined in the recent earnings press release, and more details are provided in the most current 10-Q and 10-K. First Horizon National Corp. disclaims any obligation to update any forward-looking statements that are made from time to time to reflect future events or developments.
In addition, non-GAAP financial information may be noted in this conference call. A reconciliation of that non-GAAP information to comparable GAAP information will be provided as needed in the footnote or appendix of the slide presentation available in the Investor Relations area of our website. Listeners are encouraged to review any such reconciliations after this call. Also, please remember that this webcast on our website is the only authorized record of this call.
This morning's speakers include our CEO, Bryan Jordan; our CFO, BJ Losch; and our Chief Credit Officer, Greg Jardine. With that, I'll turn it over to Bryan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thank you for joining the call. We view third quarter results as another step forward in executing our strategic plan. Net income available to common shareholders was $16 million, a $13 million improvement over the seco
componenttext:
Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thank you for joining the call. We view third quarter results as another step forward in executing our strategic plan. Net income available to common shareholders was $16 million, a $13 million improvement over the second quarter. Actions taken to refocus on our core businesses, restructure our balance sheet and proactively deal with problem credits are paying off.
Third quarter's improved results reflect lower credit-related cost as well as better performance from our core businesses in Regional Banking and Capital Markets. Our core businesses give us a competitive advantage in our markets. The Regional Bank's pretax income rose 63% linked quarter to $48 million, driven by a lower provision, improved net interest income and relatively stable fees. Capital Market's pretax income grew $15 million second to third quarter, or 56%, due to stronger revenues driven by depository customers' increased activity.
We saw positive results from our focus on growing our middle Tennessee market share. According to the recent FDIC deposit market share survey, our deposits in national increased 16% year-over-year, twice the rate of overall market growth.
Low loan demand coupled with runoff in our Non-Strategic portfolios resulted in a small decline in period-end loans. We're encouraged by third quarter's solid pipeline of corporate, asset-based and commercial real estate loans. There is some C&I pricing competition, but in general, we are seeing better pricing in our loan portfolio, as yields were up six basis points from last quarter and up 28 basis points year-over-year.
Third quarter's bottom line was also helped by a $20 million linked quarter reduction in our credit provision. Continued reductions in higher-risk loan portfolios along with generally stable credit quality enabled us to reduce provisioning for the sixth consecutive quarter. Even so, our loan loss reserve is at 4.22%. Net charge-offs declined for the fifth consecutive quarter. Nonperforming assets, although down 25% below a year ago, increased to 2% second to third quarter due to fewer resolutions and lower paydowns. The total end flow of new NPA is steady despite a couple of larger commercial credits going on non-accrual. Greg will give you more details later in the call.
It is important to keep in mind that with the winding down of our Non-Strategic loans, we may experience a little more quarterly fluctuation in credit quality metrics, given the size of our C&I and commercial real estate credits and the cyclicality of commercial portfolios. Overall, we believe that our credit quality trend will be improved. 
I'm pleased with our third quarter progress, but a slow growth economy, low interest rates, elevated environmental expenses and implementation of the Dodd-Frank bill are likely to present challenges for the financial services industry and us. We believe we're well-positioned to meet the challenges ahead as well as take advantage of the opportunities that will ultimately arise.
On the regulatory front, it's too early to know the full impact of reforms on revenue or expenses, but we believe that they will be manageable for us. We will continue to focus on improving our efficiency and productivity to help offset the impact of reform. Additionally, we will prudently revisit pricing of effective products and services as circumstances warrant.
Let me take a minute to address some of the industry issues around the mortgage foreclosure process. We deal with foreclosures in residential mortgages and in home equity loans. As a reminder, we sold our national residential mortgages servicing and origination platform to MetLife Bank in August 2008 and have a subservicing agreement with them for the servicing rights that we still own. We were working with MetLife and are allowing them in the terms of the subservicing agreement to ensure that proper policies and procedures are being followed. Through September, 2010, MetLife has foreclosed roughly 4,500 loans year-to-date, with approximately another 8,200 loans currently in the foreclosure process. MetLife is currently reviewing its overall foreclosure process and working with outside foreclosure counsel and agencies as appropriate. 
On the Home Equity side, our portfolio is mostly second liens, and, thus, the number of foreclosures remained relatively small. Currently, there are roughly 200 foreclosures in process on Home Equity loans. We believe that our risk with this issue should be manageable. Foreclosures are an unfortunate and less-than-desirable outcome for everyone involved: investors, servicers and, especially, homeowners. For that reason, like others, we believe that it is important that foreclosures, when necessary, be handled properly.
Finally, we built a strong balance sheet with solid capital base, another advantage for us in our footprint. At September 30, tangible common equity and tangible assets was 8%, and our Tier 1 common ratio was over 10%. We believe that we will be well positioned for the newly issued Basel III requirements as they become the new standards. 
Now BJ will take you through the financial results and then Greg will discuss credit quality, and I'll be back for some final comments. BJ?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. If you flip to Slide 5, this just shows our consolidated financial results for the third quarter. EPS again was $0.07, up from last quarter's $0.01. You'll find all of our key highlights on this slide, but I'
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. If you flip to Slide 5, this just shows our consolidated financial results for the third quarter. EPS again was $0.07, up from last quarter's $0.01. You'll find all of our key highlights on this slide, but I'll talk about them in more detail on the following pages.
So if you take a look at Slide 6, we'll look at our overall and business segment trends. Our consolidated pretax income increased $19 million linked quarter to $37 million. Regional Bank, Capital Markets and our Corporate segments, which we call our core businesses, produced combined pretax income of $77 million, up 50% from second quarter's levels. 
Linked quarter, the Regional Banks pretax income was up 63% to $48 million, driven by an $18 million decline in provision. Revenues rose 1%, as NII in the bank was up 4%, reflecting higher spreads in our loan portfolio. Fees were down a couple of percent as we saw continued negative impact from Reg E, which was somewhat offset by other income.
On the Capital Markets side, we booked another strong quarter as pretax income climbed $15 million to $43 million linked quarter. Fixed incomes average daily revenue improved to $1.7 million from the prior period's $1.5 million. The improvement in what is, historically, a soft quarter was driven by increased activity from depository customers.
In our Corporate segment, the pretax loss widened to $14 million, primarily due to higher expenses and lower NII. On expense side linked quarter, the expenses were up $8 million with the variance primarily driven by the inclusion of a $5 million benefit related to a VISA litigation liability reversal in the second quarter. 
And on the NII side, our securities portfolio remains stable at about $2.6 billion. However, reinvestment rates are lower, pressuring yields, which drops about 26 basis points in the third quarter. 
On the Non-Strategic segment, we posted a 15% decline in revenue as servicing income declined 29% to $44 million in the quarter, reflecting lower net hedging results, the full effect of second quarter servicing sales and the reduced size of our servicing portfolios to approximately $30 billion. Net hedging results decreased 28% to $32 million, due mostly to interest rate movements and credit marks. On the expense side, mortgage repurchase provision expense decreased from $56 million to $49 million in the third quarter, and I'll go into more detail on this on the next slide.
So if you click there to Slide 7, if you look at the bottom left chart, in the third quarter, the active pipeline grew to $469 million. New requests were fairly stable from last quarter's levels, that's the dark blue bar, with the vast majority continuing to come from the GSEs. If you look at the light blue bar, resolutions nearly doubled to $146 million from second quarter's $74 million and are reflected in higher net realized losses of $36 million. As you can see on the bottom right-chart, requests are still concentrated in the 2007 vintage. Our rescission rates have held steady at 40% to 50%, and our loss severity remains at approximately 55%. 
Going forward, we will have continued emphasis on increasing resolutions. And a note, though we've seen negligible put-back activity from private securitizations, we know that there has been increased industry discussion on this topic. And we here continue to review and monitor this very closely. As you know, the standards for reps and warranty somewhat differ between GSEs and private labels. And as such, it may cause differing trends in both request activity and the resolution process. 
As a point of reference on our historical put-backs, which again is largely GSEs, out of the roughly $60 billion of our GSE originations from 2005 to 2008, our total repurchase request to date has been approximately $800 million, or roughly 1% of originations, and we have successfully resolved in our favor 40% to 50% of this request.
Moving on to Slide 8, you'll see margin and the balance sheet trends. Our consolidated NIM increased four basis points to 3.23%. Core business NIM, Regional Banks, Capital Markets and our Corporate segment, remained solid at 3.57%. Third quarter's consolidated margin benefited from better loan pricing, lower deposit costs and less drag from our non-accruals. These positives were somewhat offset by the negative impact of our excess-said balances that we carried during the quarter as well as those lower reinvestment rates in the securities portfolio. But looking at all of these factors in aggregate, we do believe that the NIM could modestly benefit in the short term as we reduce the excess balances that we carry at the Fed and continue to improve our loan pricing. But we generally expect little opportunity for meaningful improvement in our consolidated margin until interest rates increase.
As Bryan discussed earlier, we view our balance sheet as well-positioned. Core deposits were relatively stable. Linked quarter, we saw Non-Strategic loans decline 6%, as expected. But going forward, we expect the rate of runoff to slow as the shorter-duration construction portfolios are eliminated. 
Overall, we're pleased with our progress and positioning for this environment. We're focused financially on further strengthening our balance sheet, improving our pricing and our margins as well as our productivity and efficiency. Now I'll turn it over to Greg to discuss some of our asset quality trends.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, BJ. Good morning, everyone. I'll start with Slide 10. Overall, third quarter showed continued stabilization in credit quality. Although not surprisingly, there was some volatility. Charge-offs decreased 16% to $111 million from last quarter. Aggre
componenttext:
Thanks, BJ. Good morning, everyone. I'll start with Slide 10. Overall, third quarter showed continued stabilization in credit quality. Although not surprisingly, there was some volatility. Charge-offs decreased 16% to $111 million from last quarter. Aggregate reserve declined 8% to $720 million due to lower loan balances from runoff, paydowns and charge-offs.
Now moving to Slide 11. We saw some lumpiness in our non-performers, which rose 2% from last quarter but were nonetheless down 25% year-over-year. Inflow stayed steady, and the percent of NPLs was basically flat from last quarter at 4.31%. The linked quarter increase was driven by a handful of large credits and fewer payments in resolutions in the NPA portfolio. We're seeing a reduction in resolutions as the compositions of non-performers is changing from more dated, non-strategic assets to commercial loans. Additionally, commercial TDRs increased, reflecting efforts to mitigate loss potentials by working with our distressed borrowers and adjusting as the industry moves forward with more consistent practices.
I'll now discuss key trends by portfolios, starting with income CRE on Slide 12. Income CRE balances were $1.5 billion, or 9% of our loan portfolio. Linked quarter, net charge-offs declined $22 million to $11 million. Non-performers were up at 10.1%. And as we progress through the maturity cycle of commercial real estate, we expect continued deterioration in 2011. At third quarter, reserves in our income CRE portfolio were at 9.5%, and the reserves have been about 8% for seven quarters now.
Moving on to the C&I portfolio on Slide 13. Ending balances were at $7.3 billion, up 5% from 2Q '10. Linked quarter charge-offs increased from $20 million to $24 million. This included an $11 million fraud-related credit that we charged off in the third quarter. 
As you can see on Slide 14, the C&I portfolio also includes approximately $700 million of TruPS, bank holding company and other bank-related loans. About $300 million are bank TruPS, including seven loans on interest referral at quarter end. Insurance TruPS comprised $164 million, $136 million were loans to bank holding companies and $96 million for other loans secured by bank stock. Financial institutions remain stressed, and we will continue to monitor this portion of the C&I portfolio very carefully.
I'll talk about our Home Equity portfolio on Slide 15. Home Equity balances were at $5.8 billion at the end of the third quarter. 30-day delinquencies were 2.33%, up 14 basis points or $5 million linked quarter, which was driven by more borrowers in the foreclosure review process. Non-performers in the Home Equity portfolio were up 11 basis points to 0.46%, reflecting our ongoing efforts to work with borrowers on modifications.
Net charge-offs were up $40 million in the second quarter to $46 million in the third quarter. This increase includes $9 million of charge-offs related to accelerating loss recognition of charge-offs for clients who were nonresponsive for 60 days. Due to the vintage mix and strong borrower characteristics, we expect relative stability in the Home Equity portfolio over the near term. Noting the consumer delinquency and loss rates remain highly correlated with unemployment trends. We continue to assume the economic recovery and employment gains will remain slow.
I'll wrap up on Slide 16. Third quarter demonstrated generally positive credit metrics, including lower provision expense and a decline in charge-off. There was some fluctuation in non-performers as we are at a stage in the credit cycle when some commercial loans are experiencing greater stress. And given their size, this can lead to lumpiness in charge-offs and NPAs. Also as our Non-Strategic portfolios wind down, the magnitude of our reserve decreases is likely to lessen, especially in our consumer and construction portfolios.
As Bryan earlier noted, we believe that our overall credit quality trend will remain improving. I'll now turn it over to Bryan for some closing comments.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. I'll end on Slide 17. Our proactive approach to credit has allowed us to get on our front foot. We're able to concentrate on new customer acquisition and retention. We've improved underwriting, better pricing and continued great service.
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg. I'll end on Slide 17. Our proactive approach to credit has allowed us to get on our front foot. We're able to concentrate on new customer acquisition and retention. We've improved underwriting, better pricing and continued great service. We know that we have additional work to do in improving productivity and efficiency, and we're focused on doing it. Thank you to the First Horizon team who takes care of our customers and continues to take the actions necessary to refocus our company. We're taking steps toward our goal of achieving sustainable profitability to drive consistently attractive returns for our shareholders. 
Operator, we'd now like to open the call for questions, please.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Craig Siegenthaler from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Craig Siegenthaler from Credit Suisse.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just two questions here on the private label mortgage business. The first one, put-backs from the private label side still are quite small. I'm just wondering if you could help us in evaluating the risk that there's a material increase in this area in the
componenttext: Just two questions here on the private label mortgage business. The first one, put-backs from the private label side still are quite small. I'm just wondering if you could help us in evaluating the risk that there's a material increase in this area in the next few quarters?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, it's BJ. I'll take a crack at that. We've continued to monitor this very closely, as I said. And as I said, we've seen negligible put-backs to date. So for us to monitor something that we haven't yet seen is tough, so how we do that is we just moni
componenttext: Craig, it's BJ. I'll take a crack at that. We've continued to monitor this very closely, as I said. And as I said, we've seen negligible put-backs to date. So for us to monitor something that we haven't yet seen is tough, so how we do that is we just monitor the same types of things that you do, discussion activities, where trends are and kind of the different industry views. As we see those start to come in, which we do expect, we will be as proactive as we have been on the GSE put-backs. So as I've said in my remarks, the reps and warranties somewhat differ between the GSEs and the private labels. And maybe that's causing some timing issues and activity. And we'll just be prepared for it as it comes.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Bryan. Let me add to that. We've got about $15.5 billion, $16 billion that are still outstanding. I think it's important to understand what that product is and the credit quality in it. About 55%, or $8.5 billion, is what we would define as
componenttext: Craig, this is Bryan. Let me add to that. We've got about $15.5 billion, $16 billion that are still outstanding. I think it's important to understand what that product is and the credit quality in it. About 55%, or $8.5 billion, is what we would define as, I'll say, adjustable, adjustable ARM, et cetera. It had, going in, a FICA score of over 700 with roughly an 80% combined loan-to-value. The remainder, about 45% or $7 billion, is jumbo product, had 735 or so FICA score going in and a 60% original combined loan-to-value. Of the jumbo, say $7 billion, roughly $6 billion of that was full-dock products. So we think the credit quality of the product is a good product. And so as BJ said, it's something where we've seen very limited requests at this point and something that we're aware of and focused on, and we will continue to monitor it.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just to your point, if the credit quality is quite strong here, even if there is, let's say, a modest risk of put-back, there won't be a put-back if the loan is still at par and still paying. So is your view the credit quality's strong, and that
componenttext: And then just to your point, if the credit quality is quite strong here, even if there is, let's say, a modest risk of put-back, there won't be a put-back if the loan is still at par and still paying. So is your view the credit quality's strong, and that could help offset it?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly, the credit quality, the strength of the borrower will have a big impact on the default, default leads to repurchase request. So we think credit quality clearly has an impact on it. As BJ said, the requirements for repurchase the rep and warranty
componenttext: Clearly, the credit quality, the strength of the borrower will have a big impact on the default, default leads to repurchase request. So we think credit quality clearly has an impact on it. As BJ said, the requirements for repurchase the rep and warranty risk is different in this portfolio. So given the limited activity, it's difficult to estimate at this point.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Alexopoulos from JPMorgan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, given the unfolding nature of this, that's a question I don't know the answer to at this point. As I said in my prepared comments, we're very focused on working with MetLife and understanding the process as it had been applied. And as it unfolds, w
componenttext: Steve, given the unfolding nature of this, that's a question I don't know the answer to at this point. As I said in my prepared comments, we're very focused on working with MetLife and understanding the process as it had been applied. And as it unfolds, we'll have a better sense of that. I do think that any liability, if it does exist, is reasonably manageable.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: But you don't have any control at this point as to the actual foreclosure process there?
componenttext: But you don't have any control at this point as to the actual foreclosure process there?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as I've said earlier, we control the foreclosure process on the Home Equity side. That's been fairly small. We've got, roughly, 200 loans in the foreclosure process now. The reason it's been small in the past is loss severities have been very, very
componenttext: Well, as I've said earlier, we control the foreclosure process on the Home Equity side. That's been fairly small. We've got, roughly, 200 loans in the foreclosure process now. The reason it's been small in the past is loss severities have been very, very high. It didn't make sense to foreclose. With respect to the First Mortgage business, the 4,500 loans that had been foreclosed, we rely on MetLife and the subservicing agreement to lay out the terms of that. So it's something that we're working with them and their teams to understand. And I know that they're working very hard on this issue as well.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

componenttext: I do have to ask a question on the put-back, but I also have an unrelated question. So just first, on repurchase risk here, has there been any change on either the rescission rate or the severity in the last couple of quarters? Have you noticed anything materially different there?

componenttext: And then, separately, one positive in this quarter was some of the commercial loan growth that you had, about 5% period-end on annualized. I just wanted to get a little more color on what's going on there and how sustainable you think that growth is?

componenttext: Matt, this is Greg. A couple of things. One is the balances increased quarter-over-quarter from two things. One, driven by our mortgage warehouse running up more. That's been fairly well utilized. And second is, as we've indicated, the beginning of growth due to the pipeline that we have had and as we go along through that pipeline. But the majority of the quarter-over-quarter balance growth was mortgage warehouse.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010

componenttextpreview: Can we just jump over to TDR for a second?  Obviously, a little jump in the TDR. Is that accruing?  Is it non-accruing? What's your thoughts on where that goes, Greg, over the next several quarters?
componenttext: Can we just jump over to TDR for a second?  Obviously, a little jump in the TDR. Is that accruing?  Is it non-accruing? What's your thoughts on where that goes, Greg, over the next several quarters?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: The TDRs include accruing and non-accruing. I would expect TDRs to continue to increase as we work with borrowers. And obviously, it takes some time to -- as everything's performing for TDR to then remove that flag. So just where we're at in the cycle and
componenttext: The TDRs include accruing and non-accruing. I would expect TDRs to continue to increase as we work with borrowers. And obviously, it takes some time to -- as everything's performing for TDR to then remove that flag. So just where we're at in the cycle and working with it, and as we've got the Non-Strategic portfolio lessening, and we're working with our core franchise customers, working through problems with them in the cycle, I would expect that TDRs would continue to increase some. I think the other thing I'd comment on TDR is I think we're all expecting that between the OTC and the FAS, that we'll have some clear, fair views of how the industry is to treat TDRs. Because it's a little bit opaque to everyone right now.

componenttext: A new draft just came out earlier this week. What's the breakdown of accruing and non-accruing? Is it all...

componenttextpreview: I was going to add that. I think it's really determined based on where the loan is at the time of restructuring. So if it's on non-accrual until it performs for a period under the restructured terms, it gets reported as non-accruing, but it's about 50% or
componenttext: I was going to add that. I think it's really determined based on where the loan is at the time of restructuring. So if it's on non-accrual until it performs for a period under the restructured terms, it gets reported as non-accruing, but it's about 50% or so that is accruing today. The other would be non-accruing margin.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a question to go back and it's because everybody's trying to figure out, you guys are obviously making progress on the fundamentals. On this mortgage overhang, it is sitting there and something everyone is trying to quantify. Can you guys ta
componenttext: And then just a question to go back and it's because everybody's trying to figure out, you guys are obviously making progress on the fundamentals. On this mortgage overhang, it is sitting there and something everyone is trying to quantify. Can you guys talk about the differences in the reps and warranties in your portfolio?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I'll just give you a couple examples, it's BJ, between with GSEs and privates. One has to do with the ownership requirements. In a private securitization, you have to have a certain level of ownership in the securities to then get the master servicer
componenttext: Bob, I'll just give you a couple examples, it's BJ, between with GSEs and privates. One has to do with the ownership requirements. In a private securitization, you have to have a certain level of ownership in the securities to then get the master servicer or the trustee to make claims requests on behalf of the investor. The second relates to the reps and warranties of what you're actually repping to.  On private securitizations, it's more to the tapes, whereas in the GSEs, it's a little bit more to the actual loans. And so those are very broad, high-level differences, so we'll see where those go.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, you talked about the reserve release beginning to slow. Will you be doing 30 basis points a quarter or thereabouts?  Can you keep up this pace throughout the next three or four quarters?  And where do you stop?
componenttext: Greg, you talked about the reserve release beginning to slow. Will you be doing 30 basis points a quarter or thereabouts?  Can you keep up this pace throughout the next three or four quarters?  And where do you stop?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will answer that kind of broadly. I think the point is there was rapid reserve releases as we were working through Non-Strategic. And as that gets behind us, and expecting that the portfolios continues to stabilize, I think that we would look, potential
componenttext: I will answer that kind of broadly. I think the point is there was rapid reserve releases as we were working through Non-Strategic. And as that gets behind us, and expecting that the portfolios continues to stabilize, I think that we would look, potentially, for some continued reserve releases, not at the rate that we've seen before. That's going to be driven by the economy and by the individual portfolios. But much of the reserve releases were coming out of some of the Non-Strategic portfolios as well as stabilization of the Home Equity book as well.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just put it in order of magnitude, as we've said in the past, we expect that a normalized reserve will probably run, under current accounting, 1.5% to 2%. Today, we're at 4.22%, I think the number was. So there's a significant amount of reserves that we c
componenttext: Just put it in order of magnitude, as we've said in the past, we expect that a normalized reserve will probably run, under current accounting, 1.5% to 2%. Today, we're at 4.22%, I think the number was. So there's a significant amount of reserves that we can come down as the credit picture improves over the next couple of years.

componenttextpreview: Any observations you can share on Reg E, maybe percentage opt in or any changes in behavior at all?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, this is Bryan. We've had, I think it's something like 60% or so of our customers who have made a decision. About half or more have opted in. It had some impact on this quarter. I think NSF/OD charges were down in the $3.5 million to $4 million range.
componenttext: Jon, this is Bryan. We've had, I think it's something like 60% or so of our customers who have made a decision. About half or more have opted in. It had some impact on this quarter. I think NSF/OD charges were down in the $3.5 million to $4 million range. We still see customers opting in. As we've said in the past, we expect that, net-net, that when you work through an annual cycle, it's probably going to have something in the $10 million annualized impact on our revenue. As I said, we still see customers making decisions, we still see customers opting in. The pace has slowed a little bit here late third quarter moving into the fourth quarter.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one last question.  You got a couple quarters of profitability back to back, and you have some clarity on capital issues.  And just curious what your thinking is today on TARP, and does that capital clarity change things at all for you?
componenttext: And then just one last question.  You got a couple quarters of profitability back to back, and you have some clarity on capital issues.  And just curious what your thinking is today on TARP, and does that capital clarity change things at all for you?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that our thinking has not changed an awful lot. As I've said for the last several quarters, we'd like to make progress working our regulators to repay the TARP in a practical and sensible way. We would expect to continue our efforts in th
componenttext: Yes. I would say that our thinking has not changed an awful lot. As I've said for the last several quarters, we'd like to make progress working our regulators to repay the TARP in a practical and sensible way. We would expect to continue our efforts in that regard. And I'm hopeful that we can continue to make progress in that and repay it as that works through the process.

componenttext: No, they're questioning how the appraisal was made and what value that was assigned, which then leads to what the loan-to-value was. So that's one of the main reasons for put-backs.

componenttext: Again, the part of the growth and balances is mortgage warehouse lending. We're seeing a significant utilization in that. In terms of other, we're seeing some good progress in the medical space. And, obviously, some in the CRE income property space as well, which is also an area where we're seeing it. So generally, it's in terms of new opportunities in the medical space and growth in the warehouse.

componenttext: Jefferson, this is Bryan. As we look at our pipeline, we're pretty encouraged by what we see in the pipeline. It's broad-based. It's everything from commercial to commercial real estate. We see opportunities continue to exist in asset-based lending. We saw, probably, outsized growth in warehouse lending. But the lending activity we saw this quarter was fairly broad-based, and we're reasonably encouraged with the opportunities we see in front of us.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: So when you think about non-performing assets, you mentioned that's moving to commercial as most of the legacy business. And when you think about how that change is affecting the NPA balances, should we be expecting sort of more of a flattening in NPA bal
componenttext: So when you think about non-performing assets, you mentioned that's moving to commercial as most of the legacy business. And when you think about how that change is affecting the NPA balances, should we be expecting sort of more of a flattening in NPA balances going forward as the Non-Strategic stuff just becomes less of a portion and you have longer commercial NPAs in there?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, generally. There's a of couple things. I think were at fulcrum point, so as the Non-Strategic is winding down, we're working with the commercial loans. One thing that will begin to happen is the upgrade process. So I think at this point in t
componenttext: Yes, I think, generally. There's a of couple things. I think were at fulcrum point, so as the Non-Strategic is winding down, we're working with the commercial loans. One thing that will begin to happen is the upgrade process. So I think at this point in time, what you're seeing within our portfolio is, generally, the portfolio grade's been improving. What happens is those that are in the criticized category are either healing, or they're getting a little worse. And that's part of what we see and would expect in this part of the cycle. So as we kind of look forward, I would see NPAs kind of be around this level. And then as we continue to work with them and as we can restructure as appropriate, then we will see some upgrades out of that.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sound like it's also a driver to more of that stabilization and to some extent in the reserve ratio as well. In terms of why it might not be coming down as fast as what we would've seen otherwise.
componenttext: It sound like it's also a driver to more of that stabilization and to some extent in the reserve ratio as well. In terms of why it might not be coming down as fast as what we would've seen otherwise.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what you have seen is decent releases out of the commercial side as well, and I think that continues. But yes, I think it's -- I kind of see this as just a couple of quarters as we work through this, that the NPAs will be level and then begin to i
componenttext: I think what you have seen is decent releases out of the commercial side as well, and I think that continues. But yes, I think it's -- I kind of see this as just a couple of quarters as we work through this, that the NPAs will be level and then begin to improve.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could comment on the sustainability of the Capital Markets revenues. That was a line item that we've seen coming down the past few quarters, and it had a nice spike-up this quarter. And then I just wanted to clarify on that earli
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could comment on the sustainability of the Capital Markets revenues. That was a line item that we've seen coming down the past few quarters, and it had a nice spike-up this quarter. And then I just wanted to clarify on that earlier question about TDRs, is the accruing part of the TDRs, so the 50% of that $300 million, I just want to make sure I heard you right, is that included in your non-performing loans, or is it not?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The accruing is in our non-performing loans for TDRs.
componenttext: Yes. The accruing is in our non-performing loans for TDRs.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, this is Bryan. As we've said in the past, Capital Markets will have some fluctuation around the level of their revenues. We feel pretty optimistic about the activity we see in the business for the next several quarters. And we think that they could
componenttext: Kevin, this is Bryan. As we've said in the past, Capital Markets will have some fluctuation around the level of their revenues. We feel pretty optimistic about the activity we see in the business for the next several quarters. And we think that they could ebb or flow a little bit, but we think we're going to see pretty good activity flows, particularly in the fixed income business, over the next several quarters. So I can't tell you whether it's $1.7 million on an average day or $1.5 million. But we think -- we're very optimistic as we look out and think about the next several quarters.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next on the line, we have Kevin Reynolds with Wunderlich Securities.
componenttext: Next on the line, we have Kevin Reynolds with Wunderlich Securities.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you look forward moving beyond the mortgage foreclosures issues, what is your position on TARP repayment? And I apologize, I've been trying to keep up with you so if you've already addressed this a little bit, but what's your position on TARP repayment
componenttext: As you look forward moving beyond the mortgage foreclosures issues, what is your position on TARP repayment? And I apologize, I've been trying to keep up with you so if you've already addressed this a little bit, but what's your position on TARP repayment? And then also, how do you feel about the acquisition environment today? I know we've seen in the general neighborhood down here a couple of interesting announcements with the small bank that was acquired at a pretty deep discounted price. Where do you stand on that today?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, this is Bryan. Let me start with the TARP, and they're really closely related in some sense. As I pointed out, as we went through the prepared remarks, we've got a very a strong capital base; Tier 1 common, north of 10%, I think 10.4%.  8% tangible
componenttext: Kevin, this is Bryan. Let me start with the TARP, and they're really closely related in some sense. As I pointed out, as we went through the prepared remarks, we've got a very a strong capital base; Tier 1 common, north of 10%, I think 10.4%.  8% tangible common tangible assets. And we think that we've got a very strong capital base, which really enables us to do things, one, to work with our regulators as we think about how we repay the TARP, to do it in a reasonable fashion and a reasonable timeframe. And we would expect to continue to work with our regulators in that regard. With respect to the M&A environment, we think that's an opportunity for us to put capital to work. We're going to be very focused and measured in how and when we'd execute on that. We want to make sure that we have the right kind of opportunity and the right kind of market, and it helps us build the franchise for the long-term. And we think there will be opportunities there. We don't feel any particular urgency around the M&A environment right now, simply because we see ourselves making very good progress on the things that we're focused on day to day, growing customers, getting more productive in the way we produce revenue and more efficient in the way that we produce that revenue. And so we think we've got a lot of opportunities in a number of different avenues, and so we're very encouraged about what we think the next several quarters and several years hold in terms of our ability to grow the business.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Marty Mosby with Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Marty Mosby with Guggenheim.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about asset quality improvement. And given what we've been able to see on that front with the trends, are we beginning to be able to pull any of the expenses down related to work out or the analysis on the asset quality side?
componenttext: I wanted to ask about asset quality improvement. And given what we've been able to see on that front with the trends, are we beginning to be able to pull any of the expenses down related to work out or the analysis on the asset quality side?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that continues to run down to that degree, even from the number of people in rehab is reducing substantially as we work through that. And then the more environmental costs are also decreasing as well.
componenttext: Yes, that continues to run down to that degree, even from the number of people in rehab is reducing substantially as we work through that. And then the more environmental costs are also decreasing as well.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: BJ, I was wondering with -- we talked about the reinvestment risk in the securities portfolio, how are you trying to combat that, given that we do have the low-interest-rate environment that's going to be around for a while? And then kind of a tag-on to t
componenttext: BJ, I was wondering with -- we talked about the reinvestment risk in the securities portfolio, how are you trying to combat that, given that we do have the low-interest-rate environment that's going to be around for a while? And then kind of a tag-on to that is how do we kind of think about the pre-payment risk in the mortgage side if you go from what is an inflated level but not really where we should be, given where interest rates are at. And if we were to lose some of the servicing possibility as well as some of the national HELOC volume and, also, more reinvestment risk and investment portfolio, how do we handle that comps on our yields as well.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the reinvestment risk, I think I talked about that. Our yield's declined about 26 basis points there. What we're trying to do with our securities portfolio is make sure that the structure is right of what we're buying, as opposed to looking for yields.
componenttext: On the reinvestment risk, I think I talked about that. Our yield's declined about 26 basis points there. What we're trying to do with our securities portfolio is make sure that the structure is right of what we're buying, as opposed to looking for yields. So our durations are staying very short, we're probably in the 2 ½ year range. And we want to make sure that we don't get caught upside down on the carry trade if rates suddenly move up. So our reinvestment rates right now are right in the 2.5% range. And if you look at our maturity stacks going forward into next year and next few years, there certainly is going to be a drag if interest rates stay where they are and our reinvestment rates stay where they are. But as you know, our securities portfolio percentage of our assets is relatively small versus peers. So we think that, that drag is manageable, and we would rather not reach for yield there. We do think with the pipeline that we have on the loan side, we'd much rather put some money to work there and try to get some loan yields, which we think could happen over the next several quarters. So, like I said, on the NIM overall, we think it can modestly improve over the near-term. And then it will take some interest rates in general to make it move up meaningfully. In terms of the pre-payment risk on MSR, I think our CPR this quarter was 13%. So it's still very, very low. You're exactly right. If that started to increase, we'd have it running down. But as we sit here today, we think that servicing portfolio is very manageable at this size. We very much like how we're able to hedge it and the knowledge and expertise that we have around hedging it. And so we think it's a good asset for us to help us somewhat offset some of the mortgage repurchase expense that we have. So as we sit here today, we're pretty comfortable with it.

componenttext: Just one quick question on the put-backs. Do you guys get the sense that put-backs on non-delinquent mortgages will be higher under private label securities relative to what we've seen for Fannie and Freddie?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Heather, it's BJ. My guess would be that it would be more on delinquents or where there's actually been losses. The experience that we've seen on GSEs is the vast majority of what comes back is delinquent. So I can't sit here right now and think of a reas
componenttext: Heather, it's BJ. My guess would be that it would be more on delinquents or where there's actually been losses. The experience that we've seen on GSEs is the vast majority of what comes back is delinquent. So I can't sit here right now and think of a reason why that would be different on private.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Heather, this is Bryan. I was just trying to think  through it. Delinquency and default have been the trigger in the past. I can't come up with what I think would be a good reason why you would see current mortgages be a significantly different proportion
componenttext: Heather, this is Bryan. I was just trying to think  through it. Delinquency and default have been the trigger in the past. I can't come up with what I think would be a good reason why you would see current mortgages be a significantly different proportion out of private securities as they would be in the agency servicing business or agency sales.

componenttextpreview: Good question, I don't know the answer to that. As I understand it right now, again, the reps and warranties somewhat differ on the privates. And so on securitizations, you're going to have prospectuses which clearly lay out the risk. And we'll look throu
componenttext: Good question, I don't know the answer to that. As I understand it right now, again, the reps and warranties somewhat differ on the privates. And so on securitizations, you're going to have prospectuses which clearly lay out the risk. And we'll look through and have defenses for what we think is something that we need to repurchase. And things that we don't, we'll put back.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Burnell of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Burnell of Wells Fargo.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd like to get a little more color on your net interest margin guidance. BJ, I think you said that, essentially, you're expecting, at least in the near-term, relatively flat net interest margin. What was the benefit in the quarter from the fairly
componenttext: I guess I'd like to get a little more color on your net interest margin guidance. BJ, I think you said that, essentially, you're expecting, at least in the near-term, relatively flat net interest margin. What was the benefit in the quarter from the fairly large -- or what was the magnitude of the benefit from the fairly large increase in the net interest margin and Capital Markets on the overall net interest margin in Q3?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Q3, it was a few basis points.
componenttext: In Q3, it was a few basis points.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Capital Markets was actually down, with margin barely down a little bit in the quarter. The big increase came from the loan portfolio.
componenttext: I think Capital Markets was actually down, with margin barely down a little bit in the quarter. The big increase came from the loan portfolio.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Loan portfolio had a much bigger impact. There was a little bit of an impact on lesser drag from non-accruals, I think about two basis points. That securities portfolio, as I talked about, was a net drag. And I mentioned excess balances at the Fed, we pro
componenttext: Loan portfolio had a much bigger impact. There was a little bit of an impact on lesser drag from non-accruals, I think about two basis points. That securities portfolio, as I talked about, was a net drag. And I mentioned excess balances at the Fed, we probably averaged about $600 million of excess balances at the Fed during the quarter. And so we think that, that comes down going into the fourth quarter pretty substantially. And so we think over the near term, the margin could modestly improve, just because of that.  But longer-term, it's going to be hard to move up until interest rates rise.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Aarti pointed out to me I was wrong, that the margin in Capital Markets was up.
componenttext: Aarti pointed out to me I was wrong, that the margin in Capital Markets was up.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bryan, you've mentioned a couple of times the commercial lending pipeline is starting to build, and you're obviously enthusiastic about that. If you got $1 billion in the pipeline right now, and you're pretty comfortable that most of that is going to turn
componenttext: Bryan, you've mentioned a couple of times the commercial lending pipeline is starting to build, and you're obviously enthusiastic about that. If you got $1 billion in the pipeline right now, and you're pretty comfortable that most of that is going to turn into actual loan growth, what's the timing over which that $1 billion will flow through into actual loans?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Matt, maybe I misspoke.  I didn't intend to signal that we expected most of that to turn into the loan there. We think there is a probability. We sort of look at the pipeline based on probabilities or where we have a commitment. So we think there's a good
componenttext: Matt, maybe I misspoke.  I didn't intend to signal that we expected most of that to turn into the loan there. We think there is a probability. We sort of look at the pipeline based on probabilities or where we have a commitment. So we think there's a good chance to close the loan, but we understand that there are competitive deals and we may or may not win it. But the pipeline has been stable to steady. It maybe declined a bit later in the third quarter, but we expected that most of that pipeline will work itself through over the next two or three quarters maximum. And we're optimistic that it will replenish as those credits work through.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mac Hodgson with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mac Hodgson with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bryan, do you think that this mortgage repurchase risk has delayed the company's desire to exit TARP at all? Has it pushed back your timeline, there?
componenttext: Bryan, do you think that this mortgage repurchase risk has delayed the company's desire to exit TARP at all? Has it pushed back your timeline, there?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, the key -- we look at, and as we worked with the regulators, we're thinking about all of the risks in our capital position in totality. This mortgage repurchase is something that, as you know, we've been very focused on for many quarters now. And it h
componenttext: No, the key -- we look at, and as we worked with the regulators, we're thinking about all of the risks in our capital position in totality. This mortgage repurchase is something that, as you know, we've been very focused on for many quarters now. And it hasn't had any impact on our desire to try to work with the regulators to come up with the way to deal with our TARP, our CPP in an appropriate repayment  time frame.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what about M&A.  Do you feel like you need to exit TARP in order to participate in regular-way M&A? Or do you feel like you can do that while still holding TARP?
componenttext: And what about M&A.  Do you feel like you need to exit TARP in order to participate in regular-way M&A? Or do you feel like you can do that while still holding TARP?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that it's an inhibitor, but I do think that -- but my instincts tell me that having TARP repaid first is definitely an advantage and probably preferable.
componenttext: I don't know that it's an inhibitor, but I do think that -- but my instincts tell me that having TARP repaid first is definitely an advantage and probably preferable.
